description:
A friend brought me here raving about this place and one can easily agree after the first time eating here. We arrived on a Thursday at 6pm before the rush, so was easily seated. The restaurant is nice and cozy, so you can expect a line at normal hours although they work efficiently to get everyone in and out.

Between the two of us, we shared the Garlic Edamame ($5), Roti Bread with Curry Dipping ($5), Zen Noodle Soup ($15), Laksa ($14), and Ginger Ice Cream ($4). I can't even decide what to talk about first because everything was delicious! The edamame are piping hot and drenched in a spicy garlic dressing --a must order! As for the roti, it was standard but loved the curry dipping sauce to go with it for a nice starter. Between the two main soups, they were special in their own ways with the zen noodle more of a lighter Tom Yum seafood flavor while the Laksa is similar to a thicker curry noodle soup. Even though we were stuffed, we decided to try the ginger ice cream which was amazing! I was so pleasantly surprised with the flavor, which was not too strong and mixed in with some candied ginger bites. It was the perfect ending to the meal.

This place has easily become a new favorite from their delicious food, great price point, and wonderful service. I can't wait to come back and try the rest of the menu!
author: Cindy Z.

description:
It was a cold day in the Mission District and hot, flavorful soup sounded amazing, so I decided to try The Spice Jar.
The good:
Service was friendly and welcoming.  The atmosphere is relaxed and clean.  Prices were fair - especially for a "trendy" restaurant.  The food itself was generously portioned, clean-tasting, and of good quality, but...
The not-so good:
It was bland. :(  The dumplings were full to bursting with pork, but it tastes like salt was the only other thing in there.  Pho ga was good, once I added the basil, but the broth was indistinguishable from normal chicken broth.  Not what I was expecting from a place named "The SPICE Jar".
Not a bad experience by a long shot, just a little boring.
author: Jeanne H.

description:
So delicious! I'm usually weary of any Asian Fusion places that serve pho AND ramen, but I was pleasantly surprised by this place. I liked their smattering of Asian dishes--probably because they actually tasted good!  So rare 

- Calamari Salad: The best item by far. It was large, had vegetables, and I loved the dressing. Large pieces of delicious calamari. Would definitely recommend
- Green Curry: Solid curry. Perfect spicy level and comes with rice
- Takoyaki: Excellent. Would get again 
- Laksa: Good, but you have to be in the right mood for the super thick curry soup. Would order again on a cold day 

Can't wait to go back! Be prepared to wait 45+ minutes if you on a Saturday at 6:30PM
author: Angela T.

description:
Honestly not bad of a place--great vibe (casual but hipster with indoor/outdoor seating) and flavors but it's way too pricey (even for SF) for what it's worth. Come here if you don't want to deal with too many asian food options and want to just go with the classics (choices: 1pho, 2ramen, 1laksa, 1fried rice, and a few other appetizers and whatnot). Also a safe space for those who eat ramen with forks *giggle* The people here are nice and relatively attentive. 

We arrived at 9pm on a Friday and waited ~20+minutes. A ton of tables cleared up but no one came to seat us as there seemed to be a hold up for take-out/delivery so a huge batch of people got seated all at once. 

Anyway.. if I'm paying $14 for curry and noodles with a few toppings, I expect the toppings to be somewhat fresh and bountiful. NOPE. Chicken's dryness could not be masked by the heavy curry and there was maybe less than half a palm-size of shredded chicken. Cilantro was not fresh either. Also not a lot of tofu or shrimp(though shrimp was cooked fine). Basically there were way too few toppings and a whole ton of curry (not spicy btw). Places like Marufuku in Japantown are able to deliver fresh and plentiful toppings for the same price. 

Mongolian chicken dish was $15 for what I'd consider college-student level stir fry. Chicken was also dry. The "sesame bread" side was an average, bland, white-bread sprinkled with some sesame seeds. I was hoping for the classic sesame bread with scallions inside but nah. It was dense enough for soaking up the sauce from the dish so I'm not mad. The flavors were there but rip because I know I can get 4x this amount for 1/2 the price at a real mongolian bbq (and with maybe not so dry chicken) 

Another thing to note is how every single food item came out way too hot to eat. I hadn't experienced that in a while. The takoyakis (bite-sized, smaller than average) shouldn't be that hot especially if I'll eat it in one go!! They were delicious though. 

All in all, it is what it is. I didn't come here expecting legit asian food and I'm not deeply disappointed but there really was nothing extraordinary enough for me to be paying the price I paid. Probably won't be back anytime soon.
author: Lydia Z.

description:
No wait on a Saturday around 1:40 pm :) My boyfriend got the laksa and I had the ramen. 

Laksa: Really nice curry flavor, perfect consistency for the soup! 
Tonkotsu shoyu ramen: Big pieces of pork belly and rich soup, noodles were chewy, one whole marinated egg. The pork belly was a little too fatty and the broth didn't taste super authentic, but it was good overall. 

Would come back!
author: Katy Y.

description:
Omg the servers here are soooo kind and gracious! It makes me just want to hug them. They were so apologetic even though my boyfriend and I only waited for a couple of minutes for a table. The establishment is TINY, so they really can't seat many people at once. They kept saying "thank you for waiting", even after we finished our meal. We really appreciated how much they care about the customers. 

As for the food and drinks... get the jalepeno plum wine if you are keen with plum wine! The jalapeno makes it less sweet and it's actually not spicy at all. They even add in a plum in each glass. I got the chicken pho and it was so yummy, and my boyfriend was very pleased with his tonkatsu ramen. We had such a pleasing meal served by such kind servers on a Saturday night before we went out for drinks. 

I highly highly recommend this place. The menu is not extensive, but it hits each of the cuisines: Japanese, Vietnamese, Chinese, Thai... I think that's it. :)
author: Christina W.

description:
Really cute, hip corner restaurant that has tasty asian food! They have super yummy noodle soups! 

Why I was here // My friend and I wanted to try a new restaurant and I heard from a couple of friends good things about this place! 

Vibe // hip, chill, intimate, cozy with wooden benches and tables. They have specials on the back wall accompanied by their dessert options. 

Food // delicious! The perfect winter dinner spot! 
-I got the laksa // 14.00 // really tasty and had an ice flavorful kick! The coconut curry broth was super comforting and the shrimp, tofu and rice noodles were both filling and perfectly cooked!
-my friend got the tonkotsu ramen // 14.00 // and she said it was delish! She ate it up so fast! 

Overall // service was excellent! They waiters came by to check on us every now and then and they filled our waters for us! I really enjoyed this experience!
author: Emily T.

description: Honestly my favourite place in San Francisco! The servers are so nice, plus the food is good. I've been craving for this place since the last time we came here so I promised myself that I'm going back here if my bf is at work LOL! I love this place especially it's near on my bf's house.. really convenient. Definitely coming back!
author: Jo A.

description: Another great meal delivered to home by the Spice Jar. Such a great variety of Asian dishes, and always of such high quality. The Spice Jar is becoming our family's go to restaurant for Asian cusuine.
author: Nick J.

description:
I would give this place 4 stars for the decor and vibe, but the food was too salty for my palate. Heard this place was the go-to asian fusion restaurants in the area, but was sad that the ramen was not satisfying. The broth was salty to the point that I could not finish it... I understand that Shoyu and Miso by default have a lot of salt in it, but the tonkatsu flavor did not balance the saltiness. Plus, there were not enough veggies in the bowl either. The ramen must appeal to many people since it tastes very similar to other places in the Mission - I prefer a more bland based broth honestly.

Glad this restaurant had small bites though. The shu-mai were tasty - was happy to see the meat took up more than 1/2 of the shu-mai (i.e. pretty big pieces of meat). We should have ordered more appetizers, but settled on dessert. I would come here again to try the other dishes - looks like we should at least give the other entrees a chance.
author: Connie L.

description:
The Spice Jar *delivers* with unique Asian-fusion taste and provides large portions that try to mirror the hefty prices that they charge. However, the top-notch service makes up for the pricey menu and the ambiance is truly something special in this place!

My group ordered the following items:
-Garlic Fries: Gilroy Garlic??? lolol
-Mongolian Lamb with Sesame Bread: the lamb truly is as soft as they say
-Green Curry & Rice: a bit of a surprising kick to this dish
-HANGER STEAK BBQ MUSHU WRAPS (which was big enough for 2 to share)

The food was amazing!!! The only downside to Spice Jar is that the space is actually tiny and ain't no one got time for that. The trick here is to order takeaway ahead of time and pick up your food. Take notes, young ones....
author: Vasiliy M.

description: I love this place.  I've enjoyed everything I have tried here (def get the mochi for dessert), the price point is reasonable, staff are very friendly and has a nice vibe.
author: Matt V.

description:
Such a hidden gem.

We ordered the calamari salad, salmon, pork dumplings, baos, green curry and Mongolian beef for 3.5 people and were stuffed. (One had already ate, so he just nibbled next to us.)

I think my favorite was the calamari salad, well-balanced and very crunchy without too much breading. The baos were pretty small and not worth it, imo. The Mongolian beef was extremely flavorful and impossible to eat without the rice. I thought it was slightly too salty. Green curry wasn't too sweet and super warm.

Now that I think about it, I think the ambiance was a lot better than the food itself. It's communal table style but there's still enough leg room for each party. The waitress was super friendly and overall had a wonderful experience.


The space is pretty small so tried to come early!
author: Juliana P.

description: Cozy restaurant with ~15-20 seatings space. Lighting and decoration look nice and modern. Started with some beers, decent price was a plus!  They have a variety of Japanese imported beers if you want to try. Highly recommend Portobello mushroom tempura as a starter. It goes very well with the beers if just coming in for late night snacks along with drinks. Laksa was good but basic. Hanger steak bbq was very interesting- steak was medium-rare cooked and the SAUCE, I believe, is a cilantro based. Grab a piece of mushu wrap, put a piece of hanger steak, some grilled veggies, and the green sauce, it is damn good! I would like to try other dishes on the menu as well.  Overall, I loved the food, service, vibes- it's perfect for a date night or casual hangout with a friend. This restaurant has a big table in the middle to sit along with other customers and smaller table seatings around the space. Better for smaller group!
author: Adel A.

description:
We really enjoyed the Spice Jar each time we went!

The seaweed salad (massive!) and the laksa coconut curry soup stole my taste buds away. Things were well seasoned and spiced. That laksa soup was especially swoon-worthy... My vegan dining partner likes the tofu steak, though I'm always a bit sad that there isn't a broader range of substantive vegan options on the menu. (Most things can be made pescatarian but lots of the broths have fish or shrimp.) Small but nice range of drink options. Hitachino beers always hit the spot.

Cute decor and nice outdoor seating that doesn't feel too hustle and bustle like some spots' outdoor seating does.

Servers were friendly and even accommodated a massive party on short notice. 

A solid choice for flavorful food in an atmosphere that feels relaxed.
author: Anastasia Z.

description:
Awesome spot for Asian comfort food of various cuisines paired with noticeably dedicated service. The Spice Jar appears like a hipster, almost more Westernized restaurant but don't let that fool you. I've passed by it all the time on my way back to work and after finally trying it, the flavor of the dishes definitely took me by surprise. 

The menu has a section for small bites, salad, soup/noodles/rice, and "hungry." Prices are pretty reasonable for the most part and entrees will run you about $11-14 except for some heavier protein outliers like the Mongolian Lamb ($19), Seven Spiced Salmon ($16), and Hangar Steak BBQ Mushu Wraps ($18). The choices vary by certain Asian cuisines, such as Thai or Vietnamese. Some also appear to be more Asian fusion as well.

The space is pretty limited and has a communal table. When I went it appeared like it was a good setup for dates. We sat at bar seating near the open kitchen area. 

The staff is pretty nice and friendly. Even though the restaurant was quite busy, the waiter was really kind about coming to refill water and check up on us. The service definitely left a good impression on me.

Based on the previous reviews, it seems like some of the dishes are a hit or miss, but luckily I had a pretty good experience.

Seven Spiced Salmon - Portions were smaller than expected for the steep price of $17. I wish there was more to this dish, maybe more rice or a side of veggies. The fish did feel a bit overcooked, but it didn't bother me too much. With that said, I enjoyed the flavor and quality of the salmon.

Laksa - Tried a bit of this and loved the flavor as well. The soup is veeeery heavy and hard to finish as it has more of a thick, curry consistency. It would have been better if the "soup" was watered down but this also wasn't a huge issue. We ended up not being able to finish and took it home to put on top of rice!  

I'm curious to try other dishes, and given the the reasonable prices and proximity I will be back!
author: Chelsea W.

description: Great Asian food with an equally great atmosphere!! I came here with my friend on a Wednesday at around 6pm and there was plenty of seating! The restaurant is a great place to catch up with friends, but the restaurant is a bit noisy. I got the tonkotsu-shoyu ramen and it was delicious! It really hit the spot on a cold SF night. The portion size is great, and the more I ate the ramen, the saltier it got, but nothing too concerning. The service was quick and efficient! I would definitely recommend this place, and next time when I'm in the area, I'll come back here!!
author: Lisa C.

description:
I wish I liked this place more as I had such high hopes! The decor is great and the restaurant is cute, with marble table tops and great plate ware. 

The main gripe I had was with how salty and overly flavored everything was. Here's what we had:

1) Belly baos - kind of difficult to cut up the meat. Meat was good and tender but generally too sweet/saucy

2) Garlic noodles - avoid, these were incredibly oily/salty and oddly randomly sweet 

3) Miso Ramen - I don't usually like ramen but this wasn't too bad and was probably the best dish 

4) Mushu Hanger Steak Wraps - again, way too salty. This dish was basically steak fajitas. The steak was a little tough/over done and tortillas were...well, tortillas, not mushu wraps

Overall, meh. Maybe we got the wrong things, but a 1/4 is pretty bad. Not likely that I would come back.
author: Sally C.

description:
We have come here for a long time now. I'd say it's the best fusion Asia restaurant in San Francisco. Super friendly staff and great taste. 
Often you will expect a little wait to get your table, but it's absolutely worth it.
author: Philipp B.

description:
This Asian Comfort Food spot recently opened up in my neighborhood in a victorian building with lots of built-in charm.

The first thing that caught my eye were the cans of Cafe Du Monde coffee holding napkins and silverware. This is what they use for their delicious Iced Vietnamese Coffee!!! 

I ordered the vegetarian gyoza appetizer. They were really tasty- crunchy edges, soft in the middle and tangy soy chili sauce on the side. 

I also ordered the spare ribs bao- braised for 6 hours, it comes with two steamed buns and pickled cucumber.

I will definitely be coming back to try more items.
author: Mitzi G.

description:
We had: lettuce cups, homemade tofu, seaweed salad, octopus salad, fried rice, and green curry.  I liked the beer selection.

Everything was good. The lettuce cups stand out.  Place is pretty crowded.
author: Michael E.

description: The service and space are great but the food was sort of bland and portions are small. I was really looking forward to the fries and fried rice but they lacked seasoning. The Mongolian beef was awesome but since we did family style , I had two bites and the rest was gone. I'm glad I tried this place but I probably wouldnt go twice.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
One of the best Asian fusion I have had! We got the shumai, and it was moist and juicy! Very similar to other places but high quality and very filling. It comes with four for an order.

The calamari salad was the best thing I ever had there or anywhere else (I'm a sucker for fish sauce). There was a bunch of fried calamari on a bed of salad and silver noodles mixed with other herbs and a generous about of fish sauce. The calamari was still sizzling hot and perfectly fried. The portions are amazing for the price. 

The Korean BBQ wraps were really good as well! I thought the wraps could have been better and not been cold tortillas. It was basically steak fajitas with Korean seasoning (lack of a better description). The cut of the meat was a little stringy but it was easy to get over the fact since it was really flavorful. 

I tried some of the Mongolian beef and that was really good! 

The service was amazing. The servers were very attentive and took plates at the perfect time. It was a little loud but great for a date night. There was also outside sitting but not much. I will be coming back for the calamari salad!!
author: Brian N.

description:
My GO-TO in the neighborhood. Spice Jar is tucked away in a residential neighborhood b.w. the Mission & Potrero Hill but near the hustle and bustle of 24th Street. Making it a cute little destination to stop by while exploring the area or perhaps before grabbing ice cream at Humphry Slocombe or Dynamo Donuts.

Spice Jar is quite the small restaurant with capacity for around 15-17 tables including indoor and outdoor seating. The indoors is quite lovely with interesting light arrangements above their wooden tree-emulating tables. The orangey yellow dim but not too dim lighting make it a romantic spot but also a nice place to come to with family or friends! I feel right at cozy home when I walk in. 

It can get quite busy here even on a random weekday night so I would call ahead to see. The waiters and waitresses are super nice, just a little busy sometimes. They give a family like vibe *but I am unsure of their relations haha*

As for food, it is quite phenomenal here! I love love it. True to their name, Spice Jar dishes are packed with flavors and I lay there floored by their food . A few... maybe a lot... that I have tried are as follows:

Edamame (~$6) - covered in garlic and spice, I'm IN LOVE. I would not skip out on this especially as the portion size is a bit ridiculously large. Our table of 3 had leftovers.. a rare occurrence with edamame haha.

Fries ($6) - delicious thin fries covered in herbs with a clean feeling. Def have had better but also these hit the spot and as a potato addict I wouldn't skip out on these either

Spice Jar Fried Rice ($14) - so I for one never get fried rice at restaurants cus PFT I can make that at home. But honestly it is so good here! With shrimp and chicken woven throughout the veggie packed fried rice, the flavor can't be beat. And interestingly enough, it's not salty. I think it attests to how they create great dishes with their unique spices!

Laksa ($14) - MMMMMMMM. Is all I can say. Haha I love their laksa here. Flavor punch throughout. Thinnish just right noodles. All with some delicious dry tofu and chicken. Which I'm a fan of. If you like meaty dishes tho, maybe get something else because I found myself digging for some chicken that was on the dryish side.

Tonkatsu Ramen ($14) - the most meh dish of them all. Packed with flavor but the noodles are just like my shin ramen noodles and they get very puffy pretty quickly. Comes with a good chunk of Pork Belly but the meat in this is pretty good not great! So if you're craving ramen like I was, maybe it's for you but it won't be amazing like some of their other dishes

TL;DR @threelittlewhales (insta!)
Ambiance 4/5
Service 4/5
Food 5/5
author: Sara S.

description: Perhaps we just ordered the wrong things, but our experience ranged from mediocre to bad. The pork bun is served with the filling on the side, and strongly resembled the frozen bao from Costco. The filling itself is a single pork rib, which was dry and chewy and slathered in sauce to compensate. The ramen is honestly a travesty: the egg was so overcooked it had the green ring around the yolk, and instead of chashu there was the same dry pork rib. Their calamari salad could've been good if the calamari weren't so heavily breaded and greasy. Their garlic noodles are somewhat decent, but that's the most basic item on the menu.
author: Aritra B.

description:
Always nice to find another local spot in East Mission! 

THE WAIT: 10 minutes for two on a Thursday at 1:15pm. 

COST: $35.89 before tips for 1 starter and 2 lunch entrees. 

MUST-HAVES: The Garlic String Beans are great - strong flavor, with that perfect crisp. 

Our Ramen and Laksa definitely filled noodle craving - these dishes were stronger more for their broth and flavor, less so for the noodles' texture.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Great find for truly delicious Asian Fusion lunch! 
Busy neighborhood restaurant in the heart of the Mission District in San Francisco. Seating is limited so arrive before noon for lunch or the locals will beat you to the punch! 

The lunch menu is full of great options that will leave you satisfied and full and wanting to come back to try more of their great dishes. For our appetizer we chose the Shu-Mai steamed pork dumplings which were delicious and cooked perfectly. We then shared the Laksa which is Coconut Curry broth with shrimp, chicken, tofu, bean sprouts, cilantro and rice noodles. Delicious! Great flavors! We also had a bowl of the Green Curry Chicken with tomatoes, broccoli and basil with a bowl of Jasmine Rice. All very fresh ingredients and full of flavor. 

This was our first experience at the Spice Jar and for sure not our last.
author: Barbara n.

description:
Tried the ramen. Liked the texture of the noodle, but not a fan of their chashu (not sure what cut of meat they used...more like ribs?). The soup was on the salty side but that's how ramen usually is. 

I guess they could be a 4-star for many people. I'm rating them 3-star based on my personal taste, so please take it with a grain of salt. There are quite a few ramen shops in the area that I like more, so I gotta make sure the rating reflects that.

That said, the Spice Jar's got a great space and I can tell they care about every dish that comes out of the kitchen. So don't be deterred by my review. You should definitely give this place a try yourself!
author: Joseph L.

description:
Disclaimer: Tourist review

WOW! Spice Jar was delicious! While visiting San Francisco we searched on Yelp for "Asian Fusion" and the Spice Jar was the first restaurant that popped up. What a treat! 

The restaurant is pretty tiny so we waited outside for about 25 minutes. The wait was 100% worth it! I loved the vibe and decor. It's a great place for a date night or dinner with close friends. 

We had Laksa and the Tofu Portabello Steak. I would highly recommend both! They were both VERY flavorful and a decent portion. The only sad part about leaving the Spice Jar was that I feel like I only scratched the surface. So many yummy options to choose from! If I lived closer I would totally be back!
author: Kimberly G.

description:
This is my "New" favorite Asian restaurant in Noe / Mission area. Tonight we had the pork Bao, Mongolian beef and Green curry chicken. 
The Bao was light, the pork filling tender and flavorful with a side of dry mustard, pickles and lettuce. There was too much meat for the 2 bao but that is a good thing! The Mongolian beef was HUGE serving of beef, mushrooms, onions, green onions, and bell peppers. Rich and meaty and went great with brown rice. The green curry chicken was nicely spice but just a tad on the sweet side.  The service was attentive, gracious but not cloying. I want to go back and try more of their menu.
author: Armando H.

description:
Solid neighborhood spot. It's not a place I would walk more than 5/10 minutes to or be super excited to bring my parents to but it is a good / dependable spot for casual dinner. It's not fancy and the food isn't mind blowing but it is tasty and prices are very reasonable. 

I liked the laksa- it's super hearty and yummy. The sesame miso ramen was a little more creamy than I expected but did enjoy during a cold night. I've also gotten the spiced chicken salad which was good for when I wanted to feel like I was eating something healthier :)
author: Hyan P.

description: We came here upon recommendation of local friends. The food was supposed to be really good. It was a Sunday night and we had all the time to sit outside on their terrace and enjoy the day. Neighborhood is cute and lively. The waitstaff is friendly and attentive. We ordered a  bottle of white wine and the octopus balls. The wine was decent and the octopus balls were delicious. I then got the green curry which was also really good, spicy and creamy with delicious perfectly fried tofu. Although the food is really good, there was definitely a cockroach climbing up the window right next to the food packaged for delivery and pickup. It was pretty disturbing. We were done with our meal thankfully. We then got the bill and it was nearly 80 dollars for dinner for two people...in a place with cockroaches. The food is good it's true, and the staff is friendly, like three stars. Value for money and hygiene though is not great, like 1 star performance.
author: Anne S.

description: First time here and didn't disappoint really great food friendly staff loved it outside seating very limited but great atmosphere
author: Ismael B.

description:
Is hipster style ramen able to compete with the popular ramen houses? I think so!

Service: A Very friendly and welcoming. There wasn't a moment we waited for service or ordering. The food even came quickly. 

Quality: A+ I went with the curry ramen and was not disappointed - very hot and creamy flavor with just the right consistency. From the crisp cilantro to the freshly shredded chicken, the dish was tasty all the way to the end. 
Then, I  tried the Tonkatsu. Wow, this dish was complex! The broth had so many strong flavors and none of them overpowered each other. The meat melted right off the bone. Very impressive. 

Value: A The prices are typical but the portions are HUGE!  Every bowl is filled to the brim. I saw another customer order the house fried rice and it was enormous. 

It's surprising to experience good portions with exceptional flavor in a clean restaurant (veteran yelpers know what I mean).  Not sure why so many complain about the Ramen because it's definitely THE highlight. I'm very much looking forward to coming back.
author: Jay L.

description: The menu has it all. Great for groups or 2. Inside/outside seating on a quiet street corner. So lucky to have in our neighborhood but would come even if I lived elsewhere.
author: Alex M.

description: I love their spicy chicken curry salad.   Good lingering spice.  Big bowl of everything.  Jicama, rice, hugh chunks of chicken, zucchini , cherry tomato, good kind spring lettuce.  So yummy.  It's like eating a summer bowl of goodness. Service is wonderful.  Got to try the sui mi next time.
author: Helen L.

description: Food, atmosphere and service are all excellent here and the price is always very affordable for the quantity of food. Can be busy during evenings so pays to be early or dressed enough to be seated outdoors! A must visit and somewhere we go back to time and time again.
author: Mike H.

description: Great food and service. They don't take reservations and it's such a tiny restaurant so you kinda have to be lucky to be seated... but it's worth the wait. If you like Japanese food, you will dig this place. I also liked that they didn't kick us out when it was already closing. So generous!
author: Richard P.

description:
I'm always searching for new restaurants in the Mission, and the Spice Jar definitely seems like a popular place for lunch.  Now that I've tried it a few times, I think there are definitely pluses and minuses to the dining experience.  This restaurant offers a pan-Asian menu in a crisp and clean setting. 

During my first visit, I decided to sample their appetizers/sides.  While the shu-mai were overflowing with pork filling, the aonori garlic fries tasted under-seasoned and lacked a strong garlic flavor.  I decided to try a salad during a subsequent visit, and though the crispy calamari salad looked very appetizing, I felt underwhelmed by the mixture of flavors.  I thought the calamari was fried well but could have used some salt; the dressing gave it some kick, but given that one of the billed ingredients was red curry honey, I was expecting more spicy heat.  

I thought the service was fine, though it took a while to get my waiter's attention due to the busy lunch crowd.  Given the variety of menu items, I'll probably give it another try to see if I find something truly spectacular.
author: Keith H.

description:
The spice jar is so good. A neighborhood establishment with some of the best Japanese "street food" you'll find this side of Kyoto. I love the Shu Mai, probably the best in San Francisco, and the ramen is creamy smooth.
It's my Sunday night go-to.
author: Ross S.

description:
Randomly stumbled upon this place because Google maps flagged it while I was walking. Ended up having a very nice evening. Nice ambiance and excellent service. 

The albacore carpaccio is mindblowingly good. Everything else was tasty too, but you can get just as (if not MORE) yummy food at less gentrified establishments for a fraction of the price, and that is what prevents me giving a 5 star review.
author: Renee R.

description:
I love this place! As a frequent customer here, I've gotten to know and befriend the owners. They are such warming and friendly people! 

The spice jar fried is to go for. It is a bit on the oily side, but not terrible. As an appetizer, the hamachi carpaccio is one of my favorites. It's good quality and has a jalapeño kick to it! 

The iced matcha green tea is refillable and I just can't get enough of it! It's authentic Japanese matcha quality and I would highly recommend this refreshing drink.
author: Cheri C.

description: I love this place. I can't help but over order when I eat here. The calamari salad is the bomb.com. The pork belly boa is one of my favorites and I'm also a huge fan of the mushu wraps. The service is always fast and friendly.
author: Meg O.

description:
What a cute little place! Great find for Asian Fusion food. Loved the Laksa, Fried rice and the green curry. Very subtle flavors, that tasted delicious and comforting. The fried rice had a nice kick to it that enhanced the taste! The spring rolls and Lettuce wraps were pretty good too! 

Seating is quite limited, so I would try to get here early. We waited about 15 mins on a weeknight for a table for 4.
author: Shriya P.

description:
This place has excellent food. I loved their noodle and chicken dish. The portions are quite big as well. Wait times aren't short and the place is pretty small so you might have to eat in a corner.
The parking around this place was like impossible to find on a weekend.
author: Arjan N.

description:
Hmmm I hate to be negative, but sometimes it feels like the food scene has been downgrading to mason jars and moderately photogenic but overpriced, mediocre food. I was quite excited to try the Spice Jar given the glowing reviews and proximity to SFGH. 

A lot of fusion nowadays seems to be very hit-or-miss: either they have found the perfect balance and creatively synergized diverse cuisines, or it dilutes the wholesomeness of the original dish in a lackluster (though usually good-looking) concoction. 

The Spice Jar features a menu of selected classics from Asian cuisine. If you are indecisive and crave anything within the range of ramen, pho, laksa, Mongolian beef, dim sum, poke, and fries, Spice Jar has it all. 

I tried the TONKOTSU-SHOYU RAMEN with braised spare rib, spinach, bean sprouts, soft boiled egg, and green onion. It turned out quite underwhelming from both a hard-core ramen enthusiast and an open-minded fusion enthusiast perspective. The tonkotsu broth was quite salty and lacked pork flavor, and its combination with shoyu made it even more diluted and rendered an indecisive, halfway-there profile. The braised spare rib had a nice fall-off-the-bone texture but not quite enough flavor. Perhaps the most anti-climactic was the hard-boiled egg. I guess my favorite part was the ample spinach. 

Ambiance is cozy and hip, with nice wooden tables in a cheerful, sunlit space. Something about the acoustics is off though; I was sitting across the table from friends and it was so noisy, we could hardly have a conversation. 

Spice Jar has a good concept as a homey, modern restaurant serving pan-Asian and fusion specialties, but the food isn't really quite there in my opinion. It may cater to those with different tastes than myself, and service was quite friendly. Unfortunately this was a lunch from which I left mildly dissatisfied and with $14 less... but with a pretty picture of ramen.
author: Edna C.

description:
Great food (for the most part), excellent service, and an elegant, cozy setting.

My husband and I shared the following (be warned, this was too much food for the two of us, and we packed leftovers):

1) Spare rib bao - disappointing - unfortunately, the meat was overcooked and tough
2) Shiumai - good, though a bit dry
3) Spicy miso ramen - flavorful!
4) Laksa - excellent!  Our favorite dish.
5) Mongolian beef - packed with flavor - another highlight!

We came around 7:30pm on a Thursday night, and waited only 10 minutes for a table.

The service was excellent.  Our waiter (we thought he might be the owner, but never asked) was very friendly, knowledgable, and efficient.  We felt well taken care of and never rushed, even though there was a crowd outside waiting to get in.

The setting is warm, cozy, and inviting.  The light fixtures were unique and lovely.

Overall, a very good spot.  We'll be back!
author: Barnali D.

description: My favorite restaurant in SF, it's my neighborhood go to. Excellent vibes, a great spot for date night or catching up with friends. The wait is never too long no matter how many people are waiting and the staff is always so great and friendly. My favorites are the karaage fried chicken, the pan fried garlic noodles and the laksa soup :)
author: Lindsey T.

description:
4.5 stars. 

Fantastic place for lunch. This restaurant is tucked away in an area where tourists are rare and only local people frequent. 

The space is open and sunny with a board with a quote by Julia child:" the people who love food are the best people." That essence is carried all throughout the restaurant, from the details of the decor to the items to the menu. 

A sense of energy and buzz immediately hits you when you enter. (vs the overbearing noise associated with popular restaurants)

There is a definitive California flair to the Asian fusion interpretation here. Japanese, Chinese, and Thai influence set the foundation for the menu items. However, instead of the greasy spoon alternatives and bastardization that often make FOB Asians cringe,  the chef has combined different elements to reinterpret and make it downright comfort food for many. 

I would probably stick with the noodle dishes (tonkotsu and spicy miso pork ramen) and salad dishes. To make them Pho Ga (or other noodle dishes more healthy, ask for half portion noodle and add in spinach, +$2). Call them becca's pho ga, or becca's spicy miso pork ramen.  Given my Chinese background, I am probably harsher on the dishes like the Mongolian beef that has a bit too much sauce.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
It can get really crowded for dinner but it's a great neighborhood spot for Asian food. Be prepared for a small, cozy space where you can enjoy a comforting bowl of noodle soup on a cold SF evening. I've tried many things on the menu including the garlic edamame, poke bowl, ramen, roti bread, shu mai etc and they've all been good. The only dish that left me disappointed was the hanger steak mushu wrap because the meat was too chewy the one time I ordered it. 
The portions for ramen, laksa etc are quite generous so you could share one if you want to order a bunch of other dishes.
author: Christina A.

description:
This place has quickly become one of my staples for take out in the area! It's pretty crowded and small (aka cozy), so I don't usually sit down to eat -- it doesn't hurt that I'm only a few blocks away and within easy walking distance. I've found that The Spice Jar is fairly hit or miss depending on what I order. That being said, the dishes that I DO like are absolute hits. Nothing hits the spot like Spice Jar's Pho Ga (chicken pho) on a rainy day! 

Tip #1: I love the Pho Ga (chicken pho) and the chicken salad. The Pho Ga isn't your typical pho. It's not very greasy or salty, so it might not be the traditional hangover cure, but it's great for a refreshing, warm meal on a cold day. The chicken salad is huge -- it comes with a ton of chicken, lots of crunchy vegetables and toppings for texture, and a delicious miso sauce. 

Tip #2: Small place. There's limited seating, and mostly 2 person tables. There's a large communal table in the middle so you might be elbow-to-elbow with a stranger. There's also usually a wait on peak hours. 

Overall: The takeout wait is short, even when they're busy. I've only waited about 15 minutes max.
author: Sarah W.

description: Extremely disappointed. Read rave reviews and found our way to this place right after getting off a long flight, got the pork dumplings and two of their phos. Everything we ordered was terribly mediocre. I've had some incredible pho in SF, and I'm not even trying to hold spice jar to those standards. But for the hype this place has created, the food is just about edible. I'd recommend staying away.
author: Trisharti G.

description:
The food reminds me of upscale cafe food in Japan. A combo of Western dishes with some Japanese /Asian twist; fries with ao-nori flakes, deep fried chicken (karaage) with Japanese mayo on the side, etc., Good portions -not too much, nor too little- and tasty. 

My one minor complaint? We're  party of four that ordered the mushu steak that arrived with three wraps (Chinese style tortillas). The guy asks if we want one more? Yes, we say. Later, we see that we were charged 75cents for the one wrap. Come.On. That main dish needs at least four or five wraps. Minor, just annoyed when restaurant do that without a heads up.
author: MaMa Spatula H.

description:
Pretty good Thai place. Atmosphere is meh but only because we didn't know it was mostly communal seating.

Mongolian beef was great and prices were generally affordable
author: Russell Z.

description:
Came back a few nights ago for the second time and wanted to share a quick update! Enjoyed the roti bread and albacore carpaccio again, but also tried the calamari salad and hangar steak bbq mushu wraps.

There are a ton of photos of the calamari salad, so expected good things. It came in a giant portion, and the crispy calamari was balanced well with a ponzu vinaigrette and greens. The hangar steak bbq, while tasty, was not cooked quite as evenly. It was a bit tough to chew, so I'd avoid it.
author: Tim X.

description:
This place offers creave blend between South East Asian and East Asian cuisines! Food is pretty solid, though you might find some dishes a bit overpriced. We did a family style and ordered 2 appetizers and 4 main dishes to share and that was plenty.

Recommend: short rib baos, shrimp fried rice, and Laksa noodle soup.
author: Ella K.

description: Meh...nothing exciting about the food here. Their vietnamese coffee was pretty good tho.
author: Khushboo B.

description: I have been here 2 times now and it is amazing! The location is quite small and quaint, so great for a date or meeting a friend. They have amazing garlic green beans and my friend loves their tuna tartare. The service is great and it is reasonably priced for the quality of food. They do not take reservations, but you write your name down and wait since it is a small restaurant. I would highly recommend it to those who like asian fusion and want something off the beaten path of the Mission!
author: Paige L.

description:
Came here for lunch with some friends. The lunch menu is a tad different than the dinner one. 

Food: I got the Mongolian Beef with bread. Very tasty and flavorful. Not as big as I thought (I'm a big eater) but it was filling enough. Wife got the Tonkasu Ramen. Freaking Bomb! Broth was perfect and the noodles were perfectly cooked. Also got the pork dumplings. These were so so. Garlic fries were also good. 

Service: on point.  Small trendy little place in a neighborhood. Friendly staff. Will definitely come back to try the dinner menu. Prices are reasonable.
author: Thomas T.

description: Really enjoyed eating at this place.  Went here with a friend who lives in the area, I was visiting from chicago.  We shared the green curry chicken dish and Mongolian beef dish.  Service was good, but the place is too tiny for as busy as it was!
author: Asif M.

description:
My girlfriend and I had seen photos of this place in Instagram and were intrigued to try it out. With two kiddos in tow we hoped for a quick but delicious lunch.

They were extremely kid friendly. Although limited with space and rather packed for lunch, they accommodated us and allowed us space for a stroller. Service was very prompt.

We shared the nori French fries (3/5) and each got a noodle dish- the laksa (3/5) and tonkatsu Shoyu ramen (2/5)

The French fries were decent. Freshly fried but lacked garlic flavor.

The laksa was creamy and seafood portions were sufficient. 

The tonkatsu ramen was flavorful and rich. The braised spare rib was a bit tough to eat and a bit chewy. The soft boiled egg was NOT a soft boiled egg. It was a boiled egg. 

Decent spot for a bite. Not sure if it was good enough for me to go back.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
YUM!

We came for lunch today (Saturday). We were there early, so we were the first customers when they opened. We were the only customers while we were there.

The woman who helped us was so very kind. 

We started with plum wine and what?!?! Jalapeño Plum Wine? Yep! I didn't get it, but Mark did. I took a sip. It was good! Oh... my plum wine was SUPER sweet. Plum wine is supposed to be sweet, but this was almost shockingly sweet. I did enjoy it, but asked for a Chardonnay as a follow up.

We started with Albacore Carpaccio. What a stunning dish! The presentation was gorgeous and the taste was fantastic. The jalapeño was not too hot, the ponzu sauce complimented the fish so well. And I don't know what was served on top... something that looked fried... very small slivers of fried something? I should have asked; it didn't say on the menu. Anyway.. FANTASTIC. Get it!

Mark got the Spicy Sesame Miso Ramen. He really enjoyed it.

I got the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen with the braised spare rib. It was really quite good. People have commented on the egg and while I agree I'd expect the yellow to be runny, the description on the menu says boiled egg... and it is boiled. So that's the way they serve it. Works for me. I thought the noodles were delicious. The beef was tender. The broth had a wonderful, beef flavor. I thought it was very good.

I'd like to try The Spice Jar for dinner because the dinner menu has more options. Plus it might be fun to check out the evening vibe. From the reviews it seems this place is hopping in the evening. For Saturday lunch... it was super slow. Go visit them... they deserve the business.
author: Scott N.

description:
3.5 STARS for a cute and above average Asian Fusion (I think?) spot owned by super friendly Asian folks. I came for brunch, and they have several small shareable plates and entrees, and a very extensive drink list.

* SHU MAI - 3.5 stars:
Homemade and meaty, but the wrappers were soggy and oversteamed. I liked that they tasted healthy and was well seasoned, but I have to admit I prefer the type at dingy dim sum restaurants because they have more flavor (I know they are chock full of MSG and preservatives....)

* TONKATSU RAMEN - 3.5 stars:
Decent broth and noodles, AHH-mazingly tender pork rib. Not the best ramen but a really good option for SF standards! 

* SEAWEED SALAD - 3.5 stars:
Enormous portion of spring greens topped with seaweed salad and a soy-apply dressing. A little salty for my liking - ask for dressing on the side.
author: Jess C.

description: I enjoyed their curries, salads and customer service it's the best. Highly recommend it.
author: Leticia Z.

description:
Who knew a limited menu was enough for me to rate this place 5 STARS?!1... of course, I rated them for their amazing noodles.
Beware, if you come here after 12:15pm, be prepared to wait. Luckily, I've always arrived before 12pm and was always seated immediately.

I've tried their Laska and Tonkatsu Ramen. Both were incredibly good dishes. I am in love with the Laska! Though not as good as the ones in Singapore, but differently better than all the other ones I've had in the bay area.

The ramen was decent, the rib meat was so tender that it just falls off of the bone. 

The lemonade and ginger ale were freshly made and delicious. However, that ginger ale is the SPICEST gingerale I've ever had in my life.

Another great thing about this place is the service is excellent. The waitress checked in with us every few minutes to make sure everything was good!

Definitely a must visit, and the fact I work five minutes walking distance from here will make me a frequent visitor!.
author: Josie H.

description: Great Asian fusion dishes and the owners are always so friendly. It's a cozy space inside but a great spot for a casual dinner or for takeout. My go to is their spiced chicken chopped salad.
author: Trevor H.

description:
Some of the best ramen I've had in a long long time! We absolutely loved this place. Came here on a Saturday night at 6:45pm and only had to wait about 10 minutes. By the time we left there was quite a line. It's a small little place with excellent service and fanatic ramen. I ordered the mint tea which was light and refreshing. My husband ordered the spicy sesame miso ramen which was very simple - just broth and ramen noodles. The broth was great with the right amount of spiciness and the noodles were oh so good and extremely fresh. I had the tonkotsu-shoyu ramen. Again the broth was fantastic and I loved how it wasn't super oily like other places. 

The service was great. They were very nice and quick with everything. The cost was great as well. Overall this place has everything - great food, great service all at a great cost.
author: Lisa D.

description:
I couldn't decide between a 3 or 4. To me, it's 3.5. It's a cute place and the servers (owners maybe?) were very nice. Very busy, so you may have to wait. Got seated at the communal table, which was fun to meet a couple people while overhearing another couple on a terrible first (and likely last) date.

The Japanese styled fried chicken app was excellent. Nicely crispy and flavorful. What killed the entire meal for me was the less than stellar laksa dish. There were some overpowering flavors in there in addition to chicken that seemed to have been cooked separately then added. I really was far from impressed. Probably would give that alone a 2 star rating but the appetizer, ambiance (check out the cool branch light they made), and people made up for it.

I would certainly give this place another shot. The tons of people lined up and stellar reviews can't all be wrong.
author: Devashis R.

description:
More than excited to go to a very highly regarded dinner only to be left wanting more. 

First bobble, sitting at end of a communal table with limited room and even less privacy to hear the person sitting across from you. 

The service was very friendly. Each dish we ordered seemed to miss one beat. The flavors, while fresh, were muddled leaving you hoping for a recovery on the next dish. May have been an off night, will try again. 

Parking & space were a challenge.
author: Marisela E.

description:
Went here on a Wednesday night for some dinner with a friend. The place is small and there was a little bit of a line - waited for about 25 minutes. The place is nicely decorated, dimly lit, and can get pretty loud since it's so small.

For an appetizer, we had the chicken karaage. It was tasty and wasn't traditional Japanese style. It was more in the form of American fried chicken southern style with a thick batter. It came with a remoulade sauce and lime. TASTY.

I got the tonkotsu ramen. It was a little thick and came with spinach and a pork rib. The broth was nice and smokey. Noodles were decently bouncey. And the pork rib was fall off the bone.

My friend got the wok noodles and added shrimp. The texture was great sort of like a traditional stir fried noodle dish. Too bad I can correctly assess the flavor because my mouth was already salt bombed from the ramen. But it seemed tasty. 

Will be coming back again for the other dishes!
author: Geronimo Carlo R.

description: This restaurant is amazing. One of the best hidden gems in the city. Would highly recommend to everyone to go here
author: Rishi G.

description: This place is cute and intimate. Located right at the corner of the block. Sometimes I am skeptical about places that have more than two different types of cuisines but this places proved me wrong. I ordered the spicy ramen which had a perfect kick and the perfect amount of noodles. The staff was attentive and helpful. This place is small but definitely busy during lunch. Would definitely come back again.
author: Michelle P.

description: 4.5 stars really.  Very good Asian restaurant.  We got Laksa and the calamari salad and both were delicious.  Excellent service.  We brought our stroller and they were very accommodating finding a space for us.  Would definitely come back.
author: Reggie G.

description: Loved this place! Great Asian fusion place. I can eat just keep eating their perfectly flavored edamames!
author: Hemant J.

description: It's a cute, hipster spot. Exactly the vibe you'd expect from a ramen place in the Mission. But I was expecting more from their ramen. I'm curious what their laksa or pho tastes like. It might hold true that the place is too diverse to specialize in one type of thing.
author: Yad L.

description:
Some people say, "variety is the spice of life". To me, that just means quantity over quality--like buffets. They usually suck and give you bubble guts.

Then, you have Pan Asian restaurants that serve popular dishes from various Asian countries. Usually, I'm not a fan of Pan Asian or Asian Fusion cuisine because they rarely come close to the dishes I had growing up, the flavors are watered down, and/or the fusion of flavor profiles are just a hot mess. 

After seeing some raving reviews for The Spice Jar and that they had outdoor seating so we can bring Tater Tot, we decided to give it a shot. The Spice Jar is a newish restaurant (opened in late June 2015) that took over Local's Corner which was ok but grossly overpriced. The Spice Jar's menu is Pan Asian with several Asian Fusion dishes. There's items ranging from Chinese Dim Sum items to Vietnamese Pho to Japanese Ramen to Malaysian Laksa. The prices were reasonable for the very generous portions: small bites ($5-$12), salads ($8-$12), soups, noodles & rice ($9-$14), and large plates ($11-$19). No desserts. No msg is used. Shochu, sake, wine, and beer only. 

We ordered the following:
*Braised Sparerib Bao w/ lettuce, pickled cucumber, hoisin sauce ($5): http://bit.ly/1NaltR6
*Crispy Calamari Salad w/ mixed greens, vermicelli, red onion, cilantro, red curry honey ($12): http://bit.ly/1LUlGaS
*Hanger Steak BBQ Mushu Wraps w/ Korean spices, sautéed veggies ($18): http://bit.ly/1NNmzCD
*Mongolian Lamb w/ onions, scallions, sesame bread (not shown) ($19): http://bit.ly/1KI2tb0

Based on the dishes we sampled, The Spice Jar is just not my cup of tea. Seems to be better suited for yipsters and techie transplants so they choose a great location. We were the only Asians there aside from the staff. 

The Sparerib Bao had a huge hunk of meat but in order to eat it with the bao, you had to cut the meat off of the bone first so it became messy. The bao was light and fluffy but the meat was tepid and a bit tough. It tasted like a boiled rib from the am that was drizzled with hoisin sauce. 

The Crispy Calamari Salad was gigantic and good enough for 4 people. The calamari was overfried so the batter was hard. The greens were overdressed with the pungent, sour dressing (pool of dressing at the bottom of the bowl). The dressing didn't taste like curry or honey but a lime-fish sauce dressing used in Cambodian and Laotian salads. 

The Hanger Steak BBQ Mushu Wraps (Asian fajitas) looked delicious as they sizzled on the cast iron platter. The hanger steak was cooked medium rare as requested but it was very chewy. The marinade had a savory sweetness similar to hoisin sauce, not Korean spices. I liked the accompanying cilantro (?) aioli but not with the steak as the flavors didn't mesh well. This would have been better on the calamari salad. This was also another messy dish because you had to slice the steak into smaller pieces before placing them in the wrappers to eat. I recommend that they place the mushu wrappers in a tortilla warmer because they dried out quickly. 

The Mongolian Lamb was the most traditional tasting of the dishes we tried but the only dish that I felt was overpriced by $2-$3. The lamb was super tender and flavorful. It's served with sesame bread to make a sammie but I recommend substituting with rice so it's easier to eat.

Service was very welcoming and gracious. There's no doubt the Japanese owners are super sweet so if I was rating service alone, it would be 5 stars. They were also very nice to Tater Tot who would wake up from his nap every time a dish arrived thinking it was for him. Poor guy. Food service is on the slower end so do come here when you're not in a rush. 

The Spice Jar is a small restaurant best for parties 2-4 people. The homey, rustic space hasn't changed much from Local's Corner aside from the painted walls, and addition of spice jars lining the walls. 

Parking in the area is much easier than the central mission area.

The Spice Jar may not be my cup of tea but I wish the owners well. I hope they don't suffer the same fate as Local's Corner.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
This is one of my (and my boyfriend's) favorite restaurants in SF.  
Much of the dishes served here are comfort pan-Asian delights.  The prices are reasonable for the most part.  Hamada the owner oversees the whole operation and he even remembers our order by heart!!  This place has a cozy neighborhood feel.
There are a handful of dishes you simply must try, because it's packed with amazing distinctive flavor and deliciousness!!  You won't quite find these dishes in any other restaurant, because they are one of a kind creation by the chef/owner Hamada.
1. Albacore carpaccio - comes with special ponzu sauce and topped w Deep-fried and pickled jalapeños.
2. Laksa noodle soup - savory and deeply comforting & satisfying on a cold evening, made w variety of malay spices and a small amount of Japanese curry
3. Crispy calamari salad - comes with a generous portion of calamari; The dressing is packed with flavor and out of this world!
4. Seafood cast-iron fondue - I can't even begin to describe to you the flavor of this dish, but it's soooo good; comes with bite-size square toast pieces that you can dip into the seafood fondue.
****BF ALWAYS orders the green curry with chicken -  I don't get it but ok.
author: Priscilla P.

description: I am a spice jar aficionado! It's close to my work and the pho ga and laksa are AMAZING! Love the ambience and the staff are so nice :-) I'm here once a month for sure (usually more!)
author: Devika P.

description:
Service was great. Like, really, really good. Michelin-star good. The waiter must have come by three or four times to top off my water. Plates and utensils were changed between meals, even though they were fairly clean. We were asked multiple times if everything was going well. Really, I haven't been to a restaurant with such great service in a long time.

That being said, the food was really, really mediocre, leaning on bad. The garlic noodles weren't chewy enough (maybe overcooked?), were too vinegary, and didn't really taste of much garlic. The Laksa was okay, but the noodles were slightly soggy. The mushroom tempura came out cold, so I know they don't fry it when you order it. Also, there was no hint of the promised truffle salt. The gyoza was deep-fried, like they do at milk tea shops. The salmon was overcooked (not medium-rare), but otherwise seared well. The green yogurt(?) sauce it came with was unsavory, but there was furikake somewhere in the dish that was a pleasant surprise. 

Overall, this is a restaurant I would actively avoid. I honestly feel terrible about giving them two stars because the restaurant is fairly new and service was so wonderful, but I honestly feel cheated at the price we paid for the food we received ($35/head). There wasn't a single dish I really loved, but many dishes I wish I hadn't ordered. At the end of dinner, neither of us wanted the leftovers.

I was dining with a pescetarian friend of mine, so we weren't able to order any of the recommended dishes. That might have contributed to our poor experience, but I'm a firm believer that all food on a restaurant's menu should be delicious.
author: Jefferey L.

description:
Heard about it last week but said #effthat after glancing at the menu and the #newrestosyndrome slew of high reviews by people with not many reviews. #fastforward Today I awoke from a nap and randomly decided to go. I expected a forgettable meal but was pleasantly surprised.

(^_^) Hanger Steak BBQ Mushu Wraps $18 (http://bit.ly/1EBSFZF)
Cooked outer, less cooked inner. #simbaitstodiefor

(^_^) Braised Spare Ribs Bao $5 (http://bit.ly/1hLXJFL)
Other reviewers had dry ones. #thatswhatshesaid
Not mine. Wish BBQ places did rib texture like this.

(^_^) Chicken Karaage Namban $7 (http://bit.ly/1JhcVRn)
Tender, moist. Sauce not spicy, idc.

(-_^) Homemade Tofu $7 (http://bit.ly/1EBSJZe)
Silky. Very hot at first bc of the bowl.

(-_^) Edamame Hummus Jar $7 (http://bit.ly/1MxIUSz)
Held back by its cracker & crudité selection.

The food, the owner's friendliness, and the sheer comicality of filling up a makeshift shelf with dishes (http://bit.ly/1foB6Wi) made me feel better about seating snafus. Namely, how 1) there was an empty 2 top when I arrived and only larger parties ahead of me on the clipboard, 2) another 2 top became then stayed empty, 3) I got seated at not an actual table but a shelf that they cleared of supplies & plants, 3.5) which, if that was the plan all along, could've happened right when I walked up and not after a near half hour wait, and 4) I later realized the thing in the middle is a communal table, which also had empty spots the whole time. #thingsthatmakeyougohmmmm

But yeah, #nottrippin.
author: Dan B.

description:
This is a very unexpected amazing place for Asian fusion food! The food is very diversed: veggie, meat and seafood options. From egg noodle to (amazing) salmon. I went with a group of friends and we had the seafood fondue, veggie gioza, garlic edamame as appetizers, all were very tasty, the fondue lacked a little bit of spices but the olives inside were a great idea and brought some saltiness to the dish.
Hands down for the Mongolian dishes and the Laksa dish with coconut milk noodles with shrimps & tofu, they were simply delicious and very flavorful! 
The roti bread with curry was a little bit too much on the oily side but the curry dip was very good.
To finish our dinner we all shared a small jar of their coconut rice pudding, I can just say that it wasn't my last time eating this, I'll so get it again next time I eat there! 
I'll be back! This place is heaven for foodies! So many flavors in 1 dish! Service is also very good, the lady took time to explain to us the different dishes and helped us chose our dish.
Price is the best!!! Very affordable!
author: Rachida I.

description: Honest place with great food, friendly service and reasonable prices. A combination that is lately not so easy to find in SF.
author: Claudia S.

description:
Came here with a friend for quick meal of ramen and some Asian food. Wanted to know if this placed lived up to it's hype. 

Sadly, for me, it did not. The Ramen I got was bland. You could tell the ramen noodles came from a package, as they were not fully boiled to separate. They also forgot to add the tofu (got the veggie ramen dish). Major fail. 

The mushroom lettuce cups were okay, but not noteworthy.

My friend liked her Laska soup dish. I had a bite of it, but wasn't impressed. 

Bottom line: it's a cute place, the service is meh (they don't speak much english) and the food is not anything to remember. 

Take your belly for Asian bites and ramen elsewhere. There are so many other better places in SF for that. You will thank me!
author: Sonia A.

description:
The atmosphere is great. The area is great. Service was even great. However the food was not, and isn't that the whole point? 
Food was mediocre at best, which is disappointing for an asian fusion joint in San Francisco. 
The homemade tofu, which we were very excited about came out very watery, and goo-like. Obviously not cooked enough, and when tried it was hard to swallow. 
I don't know if it's just me, but I like my tofu cooked. 
But like I said, the service was amazing and that's why it gets 3-stars. They refilled our waters often and actually took the tofu back when we told them. Although when they brought it back it was still bad, at least they tried. 
If you come to The Spice Jar, just order something other than the tofu.
author: Francis A.

description: Such a great place! The decor and outside seating makes it a really charming spot for a date. The owners are friendly and the prices are reasonable. Get the laksa and the iced green tea!
author: Chris C.

description:
I usually stay away from Asian fusion places since they're just ok and nothing spectacular. Spice jar is small but nice and cozey. Has some outdoor seating as well. I got the salmon with brown rice and some baby tomatoes with a few edamame beans. It was what I expected and was smaller portioned at $17.00. 

The food is about 3.5 stars but the service is what makes it a 4. Service was attentive and water was refilled on multiple occasions. The place is small so I would expect good service. The menu has something for everyone with ramen, small bites like karaage, har gow and bigger plates.

I would return if I was in the area and was being indecisive about what to eat.
author: James H.

description: One of the best restaurants I have eaten at in the city. The food is phenomenal and at a great price. Portions are also big! Had the fried rice, the steak strips, and the calamari salad and I was floored. It was awesome! Would recommend to everyone and everyone. Great place for a date, or a dinner with friends.
author: Ross S.

description:
Another gem in SF....

Three of us for dinner...so ample opportunity to do lots of share places and enjoy all the flavours that these dishes have.

We started with the calamari salad and it was excellent...this set a great benchmark. Next to come was the chicken karaage and it was super. Nice and crisp on the outside with all the succulent flavours trapped inside...yum.

Then there was the Mongolian lamb which was good and the star of the night were the spare ribs on a bao with cucumber and a delicious sauce...hoisin I believe. Tasted so good we doubled on these. The spice fried brown rice was nailed.......

Great night with good service in a really comfortable environment. The whole place has a really appealing vibe.
author: Mick A.

description:
FOOD: The tagline "Asian comfort food" describes this perfectly. Nothing fancy, nothing mind-blowing, but all solid. I don't think I could order a single thing here and be disappointed--we are so lucky to have Spice Jar in the neighborhood. My favorite is the veg spicy miso ramen--perfect for a stuffy nose :). That said, I think the menu overpromises what arrives. 

SERVICE: SO friendly. You come back just for the people! 

AMBIANCE: Prime date spot. Cozy, adorable, and fun to people and art watch.
author: Helen W.

description:
Cute little pan-Asian restaurant on the corner of 23rd and Bryant that is a perfect place for a reasonably priced lunch. The place is little that can get pretty packed. Seating may also be communal.

The Zen Noodle soup was delicious. It was a coconut/samal based broth with an assortment of seafood that was sweet and tangy. The tonkatsu ramen was also amazing with the meat falling right off the bone. Definitely a must try!
author: Swan L.

description:
I think the main draw of this place is the interior decoration. The restaurant interior is very cute with marble and wooden tables, exposed hanging bulbs, and tree branches! 

The food is presented well and tastes good but is not great. I got the tonkotsu-shoyu ramen. It didn't leave an impression.
author: Rica Z.

description: We LOVE this place. The food is wonderful and always fresh. It's Japanese comfort food. The staff is delightful too. We love the shu my , edemame and garlic wok noodles.  Solid sake selection as well. Solid, good, fresh and freindly is how we feel about this place
author: M. R.

description:
Shumai - 3/5
Har gau - 4/5
Karaage - 4/5
Pork bao - 3/5
Portobello tempura - 4/5 - Unique. Truffle salt.
Fries - 2/5
Mongolian beef - 3/5
Tonkotsu ramen - 3/5
Sesame ramen - 4/5

Overall, "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description: Food was alright in my opinion. Maybe because I had high expectations from the past reviews. There were soo many flies inside the restaurant which wasn't nice either. Won't be coming back sadly!
author: Shanzay H.

description: After seeing great review on yelp, i placed my first order. I called ahead for my order, and got there 30 minutes later, just to find out they haven't even made the food! They hurried up made the noodle, and I left. Got back to my office opened up my Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen, the supposedly "braised" spare rib was so dried up, it's not even chewable. Very disappointing!
author: Zoe H.

description:
This is a gem a little out of the way of the core shenanigans in the Mission. 

The restaurant is on the smaller side -- definitely recommend going towards the early end of dinner service to avoid the wait. Also dog friendly if outdoor seating is open!

I tried the Kara Age, Seaweed Salad, Garlic aonori fries, and Laksa, all of which are fantastic. 

It's like my life's purpose to identify chill, unpretentious places to eat where you can bring your friends, baes, whomever at any time and Spice Jar definitely fits the bill!!
author: Susan L.

description:
Yeah, these two (husband and wife?) are a welcome addition to the neighborhood.  I live around the corner from Spice Jar and eat here often. Great quality food, reasonable prices,  and the service is impeccable!

I came here after a few weeks from visiting before with some friends and the waiter remembered the orders of all 3 people from the time before!  Wow.  

The food is amazing and I would eat here every day if I could.
author: Gabe M.

description:
I'm not one for Asian food in hipster areas but this place was surprisingly good!
Located in an up and coming area on the less busy Bryant Street in the Mission District is this cute and intimate spot. It's a bit cramped in here so not the best place for a big group. Can look like it's filling up quickly but the turnaround seems fast. Also a lot of take-out orders too so the kitchen is a bit slow.. a good 6 workers or so for this restaurant which can only fit probably like 25-30 people.... but the wait for your food will be worth it, I promise.

The workers are all extremely friendly but service may be a bit absent as they ARE busy - responsive when called though.

Me and my friend tried quite a few items between the two of us and the only dish I would NOT recommend is the calamari salad.

Spare rib bao - as many have stated, it comes as just one meaty rib still on the bone. I was scared it was going to be a bit messy but it was literally fall off the bone tender. Definitely one of the most tender ribs I've had. It was flavored thoroughly! The pickled cucumbers were thickly and roughly chopped, I wish it was cut more thinly, slightly more acidic, and less sweet. Still a very good appetizer - I just wish it came with 2 ribs :(

Chicken kara age (not on the online menu) - YASSSSSSS. Crispy (and stayed crispy) and perfectly seasoned. Lightly battered and came with 8-10 decent sized pieces. Would be perfect with beer.

Crispy calamari salad - judging from how crispy and delicious the chicken was, I thought it would be the same for the calamari.. The calamari was soggy and didn't taste seasoned :/ The calamari ratio was about 3:1 with the greens, which would normally be a good thing, but it just wasn't GOOD. The red curry honey dressing was pretty nonexistent - kind of like a really watery honey with some spice - I don't think it complimented the salad.

Zen noodle soup - I don't usually like noodle soups with seafood because I don't like sea-foody tasting broths - but this was delicious! Very light tasting broth, delicate coconut flavor and just very, very slightly sour and hot. So good! I could eat a million bowls of these. Came with a good portion of shrimp, mussels and calamari. I wish it came with more noodles!

Overall, very solid Asian fusion place. Would love to return to try their ramens and would DEFINITELY get the bao and kara age again :)
author: Emily C.

description: Small but great. The seven spiced salmon is very tasty and fresh.
author: Elmar P.

description:
OMG SPICE JAR I LOVE YOU!!!

Just kidding, this place is terrible and everything is covered in cockroaches, the food actually is cockroaches....just just don't come her, you'd hate it.
author: Shalaco W.

description:
3.5

Very cute asian restaurant at the corner of 23rd and Bryant. When we arrived for lunch on a Fri afternoon, the restaurant (albeit very limited seating and space) was completely packed. We opted to sit outside and brave the wind. Unfortunately, they do not serve hot sake but have plenty of cold sake to choose from. 

Started with a mint tea, shumai and garlic green beans. Tea and green beans were delicious! Shumai was a bit flavorless and I had to drench mine in a bit of soy sauce.

Next came the entree - TONKOTSU-SHOYU RAMEN!!
Ramen and broth were delicious!! The egg was average. The pork sparerib was a huge portion and very tender, but not too much flavor. 

Service was very good and prompt (except for forgetting to bring us some chili paste for the ramen when we first asked). 

Would love to come back and try some other dishes. I was pretty thirsty after the meal which usually indicates a lot of sodium and/or MSG in the meal :(

Love that they store utensils and napkins at the table in empty tins of Cafe Du Monde coffee!!
author: Yin H.

description:
The Spice Jar was an accidental discovery trying to find dinner in San Francisco, and accidents don't have to be a bad thing.

Tagged as "Asian Comfort Food," you would ordinarily expect the most kitsch-y thing ever, something like a cross of P.F. Chang's and Roscoe's. The Spice Jar is not that at all. Rather, it's more of a nice family owned restaurant, and it has a really nice vibe. It's both trendy yet somehow rather comforting.

Most of the items on the menu are pretty solid - I will note that beef anything is really good. I will note that with all trendy restaurants, portion sizes leave a bit to be desired. You won't be stuffed here, that's for sure, but you could be amply full if you choose the right items.

Probably the most interesting thing here is the 1L Asahi (actually something like 0.946 liters). That thing is massive and is good to share or even have alone.

What I found really nice about the restaurant is the size of the kitchen and the service. You see their vast menu, you see their tiny kitchen, you see the workers running around everywhere, and you really feel the effort and care in what they're doing. It's amazing what they can accomplish with a kitchen that small.

I'd definitely come here again.

TIP: Get the Asahi.
author: Brian L.

description:
This weekend, we ventured out to another unfamiliar neighborhood to try out some new food. Through yelp, we found "The Spice Jar." Normally, I try to stay away from places that have too many cuisines going on at the same time. This restaurant serves Japanese, Vietnamese, Korean, Chinese and Italian(?). However, this place has raving reviews and yelpers suggested to try everything on the menu. Sure enough, this restaurant lives up to all the great reviews. The food didn't disappoint, especially the Albacore carpaccio and tonkatsu ramen. In fact, I think this is one of the best ramen I've had in the city. The chef came and asked us about the food. I later found out the chef is the owner of the restaurant. He traveled all over Asia and picked out the best represented dish from each country.  What amazing talent to replicate the different cuisines and make it his own.

We all had a great experience here. Great food, friendly service, and cozy atmosphere. We'd definitely come back to try out their other dishes.
author: Em T.

description:
*** In Short ***

Okay Asian food, seasoned and catered to an American (a.k.a. heavier) palate. 

*** In Depth ***

What's a guy to do when he loves Asian food, has tried most of what Chinatown has to offer countless times, but is too lazy to trek out to Sunset or Richmond? Check out the Mission, of course! Coming with two other friends who weren't particularly hungry (and myself as a light eater), we only ordered a handful of dishes:

* Shu Mai - Definitely not your traditional dim sum style shu mai. The ones at Spice Jar are much larger and sweeter, with wonton skin that was oddly papery/gritty in texture, none of which made for a super desirable dish.

* Braised Short Rib Bao - If you're perplexed by why you only get one per order, it's because these are also likely to be larger than you expected. Super tender and flavorful short rib, but, be it the meat or the other sauces, the bao ended up also being too sweet. 

* Spicy Sesame Miso Ramen - Definitely the most solid and tasty dish of the three, with nice springy noodles, albeit a bit plain overall in terms of toppings and accoutrements. 

If you're in the area and have a hankering for Asian, this certainly isn't terrible, but trekking a little into Chinatown goes a long way.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - There's a large single step/platform to get into the restaurant, so we opted to sit outside instead, which was marginally more accessible, because the way the table legs were positioned made scooting under impossible. I didn't look closely enough at the accessibility of the inside, for those who feel like braving the step (it's really not that bad).

Bathroom - Didn't try.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Went 100% vegetarian this time around and I was pleasantly. Limited menu, but I'm not complaining. The Spinach & Roasted Garlic Fried Rice was extremely flavorful and so was the Spicy Sesame Miso Ramen, which we got the spicy version of. Overall, great experience and I'll be back to try some of the meat offerings!

Ambience is nice and cosy...went here on a Friday night around 8 and had a 20min wait, which is great for SF. 

Can't wait to be back!
author: Jardin M.

description:
I generally love this place, but I got super annoyed after going there last night. It was my fourth time there and I ordered a soup with rice noodles (that I've had three times before). The noodles were super underdone and hard to the point that it really sort of ruined the soup. I told my waiter and asked him for some noodles cooked the right way (I didn't want to go through sending the entire dish back, because the rest of it was OK). 

I got annoyed when I saw our waiter going back to talk to the cook, them looking at me and the cook obviously saying that the noodles were cooked just fine. When the waiter came back, he told me, "He said if he cooks the noodles any more they'll break." 

Come on, dude. Why treat me like an idiot? Why not just bring me new noodles and ask me "Are these better?" when I'm spending $100 on dinner with my family? 

I told the waiter that I'd had this dish three times in the last year (it's normally my favorite). I really didn't like his insinuation that I don't know how noodles should taste or that the cook couldn't have made an error. 

Also, the one time we asked for a side of stir-fried vegetables here (because nothing else we ordered was green), there was really no effort put in. They seemed like broccoli and carrot leftover bits that were just steamed and thrown on to a plate. With slightly better training of cooks and staff, and a little more consideration, I would give this place 4-5 stars. Their food is generally delicious.
author: Breena K.

description: Sooo good 100% recommend. We had sea weed salad, portobello tempura, green curry tofu and Laska.
author: Nelly P.

description:
Cute wittle restaurant in the middle of the Mission neighborhood. Indoor and outdoor seating. Adorable, nature-y decor.

I think the best thing about this place is the service. Everyone is so happy and helpful! One time I called in a togo order and didn't know that the haw gaw (shrimp dumpling) was only for dinner but before I could even say that it's ok, the lady immediately told me to hold on for a sec to see if the chef could make it for me.
