And of course being so kind, the chef said sure. To go out of their way like that was so appreciated. All the other times I have gone into The Spice Jar, the service is amazing. 

FOOD:
-Aonori garlic fries are the best! Packed with flavor but not overly salty. Perfection.
-The haw gaw skin is overwhelmingly thick and not thin like dimsum places. Probably wouldn't get again.
-The shu mai is pretty good for not being a dimsum spot. Big pieces!
-The chicken pho tastes clean and the self-added ingredients are fresh.
-The tonkatsu ramen has a delicious broth, but the egg is a fully cooked hard boiled egg. Wish it was soft boiled like the menu reads.
-If you enjoy the taste of mint, the Spice Jar fried rice would be your thang. It tastes pretty heavy on the mint side. The portion is huge, and they don't skimp out on the shrimp and chicken. A good dish to share!
-My friend's favorite is the laksa. Heard it is a popular item, but I have yet to personally try it.

This place has been my new favorite place to go for lunch. Must try!
author: Denise L.

description: The Mongolian Beef is what you'd expect and tasty, but I think overpriced compared to what you could get at other asian restaurants. The Spicy Sesame Ramen was decent. My favorite was the Crispy Calamari Salad, but I don't know if I loved it enough to go back just for that item. I'd maybe return when I have more money to spare! :P
author: Vicky P.

description:
Super rich, super tasty East Asian comfort food.  Nothing healthy about this joint but ingredients are fresh and the flavor is on fleek.

The menu is fairly compact but in a very good way, a diversity of choices but no decision anxiety from a multi-page menu.  We started with the pork Shu-Mai which were solid, very well prepared but not epic.  Same for the crispy spring roll, they were a bit pedestrian.  The mains and sides were the 4-star caliber dishes: we went with the Spinach and Roasted Garlic Fried Rice (strong in flavor, only for garlic lovers), the Mongolian Chicken which was super savory and a tad too rich but overall pretty epic in flavor, and the garlic green beans which had the right balance of garlic and sweetness and salt were also the bom dot com.  

Service was friendly but the dishes were staggered in an non-ideal way, apps came out together but then there was about a 20 min wait after we finished those before our first entree came out (the fried rice), and then another 10 mins before the other two dishes (chicken and green beans) came out.
author: Saminda W.

description:
The Spice Jar is a relatively new Asian spot in the Mission, bringing homey comfort food from all different Asian cuisines. I wouldn't exactly call it fusion because they somehow bring in distinct flavors from each culture in an authentic way. My boyfriend and I came in on a Tuesday, and ended up waiting almost half an hour for a table, which goes to show just how popular it is. We started with the chicken lettuce wraps, a simple dish but full of flavor. I loved the addition of the mushroom with the minced chicken, helping to cut the natural saltiness of the dish. We also tried the har gao, which was definitely on the doughier side but great in terms of portion size. 

For entrees, we had the tonkatsu ramen and the Spice Jar fried rice. The flavor of the ramen broth was amazing as it tasted like the pork had been stewing for hours. The fried rice was generous in shrimp and chicken portions, but definitely a little too salty for me. Overall, it tasted as close to home-cooked as you can get from a restaurant in the city!
author: Ashley T.

description:
I have been here twice. For dinner and lunch service. When I first stumbled upon this place about two months ago via Yelp I couldn't be more excited to check out an Asian cuisine in the Mission. 

First time I came for dinner. Ordered: 
shu Mai, spare rib bao and homemade tofu. Previous review I read saying the tofu was a must order. It was just okay to me. The wasabi salt was a nice touch though. Really enjoyed the "fall of the bone" spare rib bao and the shu Mai. Don't forget to try the Buddha beer! 

Another visit for lunch ordered the Zen noodle soup (order was split with a friend) and the har gow. The spices in the soup were on point! The serving was just right for a lunch portion not leaving us overly stuffed. And don't pass up the ginger mint lemonade. Im weary about anything ginger. That too much gingery taste but it was the perfect blend. So good! 

Don't expect your authentic Asian cuisine here. It's Asian fusion and my kind of Asian Comfort food especially because of all the spices and flavors.  (I am Asian, well Filipino.  Authentic Chinese is my least craved food. I'd rather have Panda Express lol)   Look forward to returning and trying more dishes.
author: Erica M.

description:
I'm usually quite wary of Asian "fusion" restaurants, as it seems to cater towards a crowd unused to specific cuisines. The interior design is very cosy, country home; while adorable, it almost reinforced my expectation of an underwhelming experience, due to cognitive dissonance. That being said, The Spice Jar pleasantly surprised me. I sampled an assortment of dishes and enjoyed all of them.

I started with the Crispy Calamari Salad--a generous portion of fresh greens, topped with delicious, lightly breaded calamari and red honey curry dressing. The little critters were crisped perfectly and didn't overpower or wilt the salad leaves.

I ordered the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen next, and also loved it. I'm used to eating delicious ramen at food trucks, but this was truly a treat. The rib was fall-off-the-bone tender, and the broth was flavorful and substantial without being too salty. The noodles were cooked just right, with a bit of bite to them. The hard boiled egg was done just right too. 

The couple who owns the restaurant are truly charming and wonderful. I've eaten here a few different times, and in recognizing me, they brought some Aonori Garlic Fries on the house. Yum! I was happy to see, upon my more recent visit, that they'd hired some wait staff. I can't imagine how insane opening weeks must have been with just the two of them doing all of the work--from cooking, to waiting on tables, busing, etc. 

The interior design is worth mentioning again, because it is so unexpectedly adorable. The bottom of tables are adorned with material that feels like mattress topper--it prevents you from bruising yourself while shifting your legs. I almost want all the restaurants I go to to adopt this methodology. I'm so clumsy, it definitely saved me on multiple occasions.

Definitely eat here.
author: Nicole C.

description:
When I first drove by The Spice Jar, I really thought it was going to be a specialty spice shop! After a quick search on yelp, I was wrong! YAY! Nothing against spice shops, but I rather eat than cook! HA! We arrived a little before 5:30pm (on a Thursday), no wait & no need to write our name on the waiting list! It was even sweet how the owner took the time to talk to us before the place quickly filled up! :) 

Our Dinner:
1.) Crispy Spring Roll Fair  
2.) Edamame Hummus Tasty! 
3.) Har Gow (pork dumpling) Yum
4.) Shu Mai (shrimp dumpling) Good!
5.) Spare Ribs Bao Good! Should be called spare rib singular no "s") since you only get one.
6.) Spinach & Garlic Rice Unique
7.) Zen Noodle Soup (Coconut based sambal broth, calamari, shrimp & black mussel YUM

Our complete meal for 2 people (before tax) was only $27 each! Not bad at all!! Staff was friendly, checked in on us & kept our waters full! Will return to try the tonkatsu ramen, portobello tempura with truffle salt & Mongolian beef! I hope to see more mission locals here because the owners is so nice!!
author: Geraldine R.

description: Family owned sweet lunch spot in the mission. Super fresh food and many options. It's definitely not classic assign food of any sorts but it's really delicious. Our favorites are their seaweed salad, spicy miss ramen, Mongolian beef and calamari salad.
author: Maya R.

description: Really enjoyed my meal here, versatile menu from Dumplings to ramen to delicious hanger steak. Good selection of Small plates for sharing, and main meals are definitely large enough to share. Everything I tried was very tasty, busy place but the service still remained attentive and friendly. I will be returning to try more.
author: Nadia H.

description: Really cute neighborhood restaurant with interesting menu.  The calamari salad is huge and the standout dish on the menu.  Other options are fine but not worth going out of your way for.
author: Alice C.

description:
Yummy! Came here on a Sunday and the wait was not too bad. For our party of 4, we waited about 15 min. 

The location is very tiny so think ahead if you are planning on coming with a big party. The decor was very nice and cute. The staff was great. They were very attentive and friendly.

My party and I ordered a bunch of small bites and couple main dishes and everything was tasty! I especially liked the garlic fried rice and Mongolian lamb. 

Overall I will definitely recommend!
author: Arda S.

description:
The place was super cute, the vibe is great. 

It's starts out like this... a vegetarian, 2 vegans, and a normal guy enter a restaurant and order: 

- portobella mushroom tempura: one of my favorite dishes of the night, comes with a lime for a nice hit of acidity. well balanced, crispy and meaty. 
- vegetable gyoza: really good, but fried for those of you that care. They may have been the ones from Trader Joe's, but they're still good.
- Homemade tofu: it's not for everyone, and not what most people expect. It's much silkier, and soft. The flavor's a bit deeper, almost like you might imagine plaster might taste (but in a good way?)

- roti w/ curry (aka roti prata). delicious. I don't know anyone who's messed up this dish, given that it's flaky layers of butter + curry. 

- garlic noodles (I didn't try this)
- veggie ramens. peanutty flavor and pretty good. the ramen itself is fresh and great, the broth is much better than most do with a veg broth. 

Overall, a good space, reasonably priced. I'd be open to going back, but I wouldn't initiate.
author: Dimple B.

description:
I've been here 3 times now and some my favorites include the Laksa, miso ramen, and the seaweed salad (actually seaweed mixed with a giant bowl of greens). Nothing that I've had here is conventional-- the laksa is surprisingly thick, the calamari on the calamari salad is super thinly sliced/tough, and the shrimp dumplings (ha gow) have too much dough (which makes the dumplings bigger than usual and awkwardly sexual looking when you try to lift one up :). ) 

Despite my reservations, though, I'll be back because I cannot help liking the couple that owns this spot. I feel like I'm eating at my aunt's house.. sometimes the food lacks precision but whatever! Your aunt made it, and how dare we criticize her cooking! It's more than tasty enough for me to revisit since I live nearby. This spot merits the title Locals Corner (the name of Spice Jar's predecessor) way more than that place ever did!
author: Jean L.

description: Some of the fastest service I've had in any asian style restaurant. Dishes were delicious, the portions were definitely trending on the larger style.
author: Lucy F.

description: I love this place . its a ma and pa style restaurant where they cook everything in house . its a bit of asian fusion , but done very very well . a bit of dim sum , traditional Japanese and Chinese dishes .. and some great desserts and wine . Very friendly staff .. Must try is the Pho Ga chicken noodle soup and the Shu Mei with home made mustard sauce !!! only wish they made soup dumplings .. then it would be the perfect restaurant
author: Micah W.

description:
ahh! i've had this spot bookmarked for a while now, and am really glad to try it last night! came in with a friend for small quick bites before seeing a show down the street - the place was really popular for a wednesday night!  pretty good location too! 

restaurant is pretty small with a long communal table and maybe 5-6 surrounding 2-4 tops. we were seated at the end of the communal space, which was perfect.  we shared: hummus, pork rib bao, laksa, and mushroom tempura. everything was pretty yum - my fave (as expected) was the pork rib bao!  really good flavor and super tender - i just wish that the bao wasnt as huge (i prefer a high meat to carb ratio...my pseudo low carb diet!). laksa was pretty nomsies - great flavor and good chewiness on the noodles.  the mushroom tempura i probably could have done without - lacking saltiness (my friend dipped them in laksa broth) and was a bit soggy.. and i didnt even get to try the hummus because my friend devoured the entire thing!

i would totally come back for the other items on the menu - notably the karaage and ramen! the service was super fast and friendly - you can tell its a family business and theyre very very courteous!
author: Christina L.

description: We love this place for lunch. The food we tried so far tastes great. We get the calamari salad, laksa and fries quite often and they never let us down. Service is very kids friendly.
author: Dr. Cordula K.

description:
The Spice Jar offers favs from many asian countries. no banh mi, baos, nor sammies though..
seating is a communal table, 6 tables seating 2, and a bench facing window seating 3.

eats: pho ga(9)
-light herbal broth with faint chicken flavor, no msg tasted. 
-chicken schreds dry, tasteless
-sure there was noodles, not enough to notice.

-chicken kaarange Nanban(7)
 8 pieces fried, dry, not juicy, fresh though
came with a dip that didn't improve the chicken, taste too subtle?

foodnotes:
-food definitely made to order, 20 minutes before it arrived
-never got water, never was asked. noticed all other tables got water
doing my part to deal with the drought, didn't ask for water, just drank the soup
-smelled the curry on next table, very potent!
maybe the tonkotsu ramen would have been a better.choice.
3.5 stars
author: Victor G.

description: Definitely an interesting restaurant, first in an out of the way location, definitely an Uber ride if you are staying in downtown SF which I was.  The place is small and they have an open seating model meaning we were sat literally at a big table right next to others, always a strange dining experience.  We arrived at 7:30pm and the place was jammed! Had to wait about 15 for a table!  For an app we had the homemade Tofu and vegetable gyoza.  The Tofu was interesting almost comes out as a fondu, not what we were expecting but not bad, not great! The vegetable Gyoza was good! For my entree I had the Mongorian chicken.  It was good not great.  Overall a decent restaurant, cool atmosphere but tight and strange seating.
author: Brian S.

description: I favourite place in all of mission. Lovely service by lovely people and he food is always to die for. Thank you for many great meals!
author: Rina J.

description:
First official day of business for The Spice Jar yesterday...

Mr. J and I went to check them out last night.  We were lucky that our wait wasn't too long, 15-20 minutes top.  But, they were definitely busy for a first day.

After some pick and choose, we got the followings:

Har Gow - The skin texture was wrong.  It tasted like mochi or Korean rice cakes.

Braised Spare Ribs Bao - The meat was a little dry and the bao itself was not great.

Homemade Tofu - This was not the silky kind we thought it would be.  The texture was more dense and firm.  This could be more of a personal preference thing.  The wasabi salt that came with it was a good idea, but you can't really taste the wasabi part though.

Garlic Green Beans - The beans were a little mushy.

Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen - Mr. J and I thought the ramen was not bad.  But, we both think a good ramen still need some good chashu to go with it.

Laksa - I am always searching for a good laksa.  This is probably not your most authentic laksa, but it is so far my favorite in the Bay Area.  The soup was not as thick and heavy as most of them out there and it got a little kick to it.  I pretty much down the whole bowl.

Coffee Panna Cotta/Jello - We were lucky to try this not on the menu yet dessert.  It was delicious!  A little less in portion size and add some fresh seasonal fruits on top would make it even better.

I'd come back just for the Laksa!  And, maybe try some more items on the menu.  Will try to stay away from the more "Chinese-ish" dishes though.  We had better and probably have a higher standard since we are Chinese.
author: Kay Y.

description: Fucking amazing! Food is so good and fresh. Seaweed salad, beef mushu, drinks and more. Such a great place! Service was good and atmosphere is a bit loud but great.
author: Danny B.

description: We stumbled into this gem one late night after watching a show from the Victoria Theatre 2 yrs ago. We've been hooked since then. We try to drop by whenever we're in San Francisco. Our favorite dishes are the Laksa and the Calamari salad. I highly recommend this place!
author: Evelyn J.

description:
What can I say? This place is delicious and the people are super friendly. I had the Laksa (a Chinese & Malay combo; this is not trendy "Asian fusion" it's diaspora food, people!) and really enjoyed it. The space is small, but the decor is really nice and it fills a gap in the culinary offerings in this area. Also, it's a short walk from my cousin's place, a great addition to the neighborhood. I'm a fan.

Fyi, kitchen closes at 9:45pm
author: Cassidy P.

description:
This side of the mission has been Long overdue for a place like this. I'm really a sucker for Ramen so I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen that immediately blew me away. I also had Beer on tap and they have really good wine list. Although I didn't have any wine. This spot is family and neighborhood friendly. I'm happy these guys are here. Lunch is noon-2:30 and then dinner is 5:30-?   

Now I'm going to go take a nap.
author: Joseph M.

description:
The Spice Jar is just the right establishment The Mission has been missing. When you think Asian food, you wouldn't normally hit up this area that's for sure.

This restaurant opened a little over month ago now (June 30th) and I can foresee it becoming much more popular in the future. We ordered a bunch of dishes to try and everything was solid.

We started out with the Albacore Carpaccio, definitely a MUST-TRY for raw fish lovers. The fish was fresh and lightly covered in a house-made sauce with fried onions and small jalapenos on top. Each bite was amazing. Then we moved onto the Calamari Salad which lacked dressing but fear not...just ask them for dressing on the side, they're quite accommodating! I thought the fried calamari was cooked well and added a great crunchy texture to the salad. 

We also got their Braised Spare Ribs Bao which is not the best bao I've ever had but it was pretty good nonetheless. Note that you'll have to slide the meat off the bones yourself before eating it in the bao but it does come right off pretty easily. It's said that they slow cook it for 5 hours. Our last dish was the Chicken Green Curry and it was quite tasty with a spicy kick. The curry came with eggplants and small cherry tomatoes which I found a bit different from the usual recipe but I found it refreshing. For drinks we ordered their Mint Ginger Basil Lemonade and we both really liked it.

My goal is to come back and try everything else real soon.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Finally, a great and AFFORDABLE restaurant in my hood! The menu is a mix of cuisines from various Asian countries (Japanese, Chinese, Thai.. maybe even more), and each dish is done very well. We loved the fried calamari salad and the chicken nanban karaage. Even the Thai green curry was pretty delicious. The only minor issue we had was our tonkotsu ramen -- the broth was definitely milky and porky, but it needed just a little more salt. Still, though, think of it as a "lighter" broth and it was still good.

I'll definitely be back, especially since it's so close to where I live!
author: Kazu O.

description:
Pros:  great tasting food, bountiful servings and exceptional value for your money spent. I recommend the Mongolian Beef dish.  

Cons: limited seating, no reservations, extremely limited parking options nearby.  

Take Uber or Lyft to this neighborhood gem and avoid the parking hassle. Enjoy a nice brew while you wait for a table.  Finally, enjoy one of SF's hidden gems.
author: Anthony K.

description: Adding another star because I come here quite often and have had way better experiences than my original. I still would not recommend the calamari salad, but would recommend the green curry or their poke bowl or the beef bowl. I think about their green curry sometimes. The food here is very fresh and made with care. The husband and wife ( I'm guessing ?) that run the Spice Jar are so sweet and will guarantee great service. Another thing about the Spice Jar that I love is that they offer brown rice and cook it perfectly. I have yet to come for dinner, but I think it is the perfect place for lunch with a friend.
author: Isabella G.

description:
Not bad neighborhood eatery.

Finding a spot +'s:
+ Fried rice $9 with spinach/egg/garlic or the spicy version $9 work. We had the latter and I enjoyed it.
+ Decor is basic and unfanciful.
+ Service was super friendly and nice.

Finding another spot -'s:
- Tonkatsu ramen for $12 doesn't stack against Orenchi and Halu for nearly same price. The egg was not not seasoned or oozing with yolk. It was a hardboiled egg. Broth not flavorful but noodles were decent.
- Har gow $5 is a hike in price because you're out here and there's no Chinese dim sum in sight. For that price and convenience I guess go for it if you must have it. Skin was thick.

Think it's an A-OK spot if you live or visit the area. Just not worth a Lyft or Muni #27 ride.
author: Yiven C.

description: Cute place. Definitely comfort food and nothing mind blowing. The spicy miso ramen was good. Ample meat in the lingo loan beef dish too.
author: Janice C.

description:
This is a fantastic place! The food is incredibly delicious and I say that as someone who has literally tried everything on the menu. The owners have brought an obvious passion for cooking and eating to their restaurant and are very friendly and humble about the wonderful food they create. The staff is attentive and welcoming. The price is quite reasonable and I have never once had a bad experience or left hungry. If I had to recommend a favorite I couldn't, just try it all. Spice Jar is easily one of my favorite restaurants. I drive up from redwood city once a week at least to eat here. Thanks for the wonderful experiences guys! Keep churning out the magic.
For those of you that don't like a wait time, eat the garbage you usually eat this is well worth the wait.
author: Void S.

description: Spice jar is the most quaint restaurant in a really cute part of town. Serving the most delicious food. Everything on their menu is a must try from the rice to the laksa to the beef. You have to get their house made ginger lemonade, refreshing and delicious. Even though it's small and takes no reservation. The wait is never that long and the service is impeccable with a husband and wife running it together. Both very pleasant and kind. If you haven't been to this neighborhood gem , you have to go!
author: N J.

description:
Wish I could give them more stars, but overall the food was tasty but nothing special. I do think the restaurant has a cute theme of popular comfort asian foods. 

Food: I got the Aonori French fries and tonkatsu ramen. Overall, the fries were pretty basic--couldn't really taste a big difference either Aonori (seaweed) on there. Think it could have been nice with a dash of salt sprinkled on top. The ramen was in all honestly pretty subpar if you are looking for an authentic bowl of ramen. However, it was still tasty and the rib meat was very tender. I would love to come back and try some of their other dishes and re-review this place 

Service: For service alone, I would give this place 5 stars. They had one waitress who was serving everyone and she was very attentive and nice. Sometimes the cook in the kitchen would even come up front to help out, when things got busy. 

Atmosphere: super cute restaurant. Seating is a bit limited. It is a cute place to come with a friend or two for a relaxed meal or weekend brunch. They seem to have a pretty decent drink menu of options as well.
author: Christy C.

description: Best ramen in SF, and the steak "mushu" is delicious.  They just added Vietnamese iced coffee to the menu and it's great, if a bit overpriced.  Mushroom lettuce wraps are also yummy.  I do wish they would add a few more items to their menu though! Efficient service and the food is always good!
author: Rachel M.

description: Such wonderful service. Cute decor and the food is no frills and delicious. It is a small place so expect lines, but where in SF are there no lines?
author: Trisha H.

description: The service here is super friendly.  The place is casual, clean, modern with an open kitchen.  Love their Fried Rice and also the Calamari Salad.  The calamari pieces are perfectly fried... one of the best Calamari dishes in the city.  So good!
author: Paul K.

description:
Came back recently again and got to try one of their specials, which was a poke bowl. The poke bowl included albacore, salmon, avocado, red onions, seaweed, their special sauces... and you can decide if you would like it with rice, salad, or 1/2 rice and 1/2 salad. I went the last option, so I can get some healthy greens and my carbs. 

Bottomline: It's not as amazing as Southern CA poke bowls, but this was enough to satisfy my poke bowl cravings. I'd definitely order it again if it's on their specials!
author: Cassy H.

description: It seems as though I can't get enough of this place. Everything about it is perfect. The atmosphere, location, the food and people are spot on. I absolutely love the calamari salad which I order every single time and the tonkotsu-shou ramen soup is heart warming. I've only tried the garlic edamame off the appetizer list and that truly is Asian comfort food. So good. Just go already :)
author: Victoria D.

description: We went to this place because my cousin knew the owner when he was in LA.  Although off the beaten path, the restaurant is in a cute neighborhood. We were at the Timbuk2 warehouse and we walked over to the restaurant.  I had the miso ramen and nori fries.  They were great. The owner sent over the calarmi salad and fried rice.  Both were great and I don't think that I could have eaten another bite.  While I don't live in CA, if you are in the Bay Area, I would suggest that you make it a point to eat here.  You need to come right @ 11:30 when the open up to get a seat.
author: A.C. N.

description: Yummy food, everything on the menu looks great. Would highly recommend the roti and curry appetizer
author: Emily A.

description:
This palce is amazing. Expect a wait time of 20 min. I went with 5 of my friends and we ended up trying practically over 50% of the dinner menu. Every single thing that we ate was delicious. It's little oily but amazingly tasty. 
It's difficult to find a table for 6 there as it's a very small place.
A must try - the beans appetizer and Mongolian lamb
author: Akhil R.

description:
The service at The Spice Jar was absolutely incredible. Everyone is super friendly. I came here with a friend and we split the garlic fries and I ordered the vegetarian ramen and she ordered green curry. Their menu is quite diverse. 

Garlic Fries: 4/5 The garlic fries were amazing.

Vegetarian Ramen: 3/5 The ramen was not all that great (it was not traditional ramen). The consistency and taste of the noodles in the ramen was the one salvaging factor. Their tofu was very well cooked. 

All of their entree sizes are huge. (2 people can definitely share an entree and it is served very hot)
author: Shilpa M.

description:
Being Asian, a foodie, and traveler to Asia, I know Asian food well. This place has a great vibe and excellent service. 

But food needs a few key touch ups to meet essential Asian culinary standards.  

We had lettuce cups - flavor not bad but lacked the Fire of the Wok, the sizzle that comes from hot flames and wok tossing,

Had their tonkatsu ramen, which was disappointing.  Soup was lukewarm and too salty. Noodles tasted like prepackaged ramen kits from a Japanese market. And the egg yolk was fully cooked - that's an abomination to the basic art of ramen. Yolks of the boiled egg should always be soft and gooey.

We also had their grilled skirt steak which came out on a sizzling platter. That was the best dish of the nite. Basically fajitas with an interesting creamy cilantro sauce.
author: J H.

description:
My husband ate at this establishment on Saturday night with his buddy. The next morning he had food poisoning. Please stay away from their salmon dish.

Usually I like to give new hip places a chance, but after seeing my husband suffering the last couple of days, no thank you.
author: Shelley L.

description:
Found this spot by just walking around the neighborhood. The design/style caught my eye, especially the beautiful art/lighting piece in the center of the room. 

The menu has so many things that all sounded appealing. We went for a few things and split them. Portions are BIG! 

The Garlic Edamame was delicious but would only order if you want to share them between 3/4 people because it's a lot of edamame. 

The Tonkatsu Ramen tasted really fresh. Love the rib that comes in it. The meat practically falls off the bone and adds to the broth.

The Mongolian Beef was tasty and nice to try it with bread - although I would have preferred it with rice. 

It's a great find though. Go before a line of Mission Techies find it.
author: Stanley B.

description: This is a great little restaurant serving up Asian curry's and other dishes. My fiance had the garlic noodles with chicken which was amazing. I had the green curry which was also really good (Spicy). It is always crowded and the food can take a while to come out, but if your not in a rush you won't be disappointed!
author: David S.

description: Although ambiance was original, the food was not as great as the pictures. Both entrees we ordered had barely any veggies. Think about this place as an upscale and over priced Chinese take out. I got to say, the plum wine was really good, as well as the braised short ribs. But the entree itself was not impressive at all.
author: Demi G.

description: Delicious, casual spot. I've enjoyed both their beef dishes and their soups. Also the wait isn't that long, especially when they allow you to order wine while you wait. One question though, is it just me or have the prices gone up a bit?
author: Erin W.

description: By far, my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Anytime I'm leaving the city for an extended period of time, I have to come here before I go. Everything is amazing, but we always have to get the Hangar Steak Wraps for sure.
author: Michael S.

description:
Average quality food, but efficient service.
The ramen was wasn't so flavorful and the tofu wasn't good either unfortunately.
Nice location and kind servers.
There is a big table to share with other customers. Too bad we ended up right next to a group of rude people, who wouldn't even slightly move to make room for us (they were occupying more than their designated area).
author: Barbara U.

description: Good food but if you have the patience, wait for the table inside the restaurant. We ate outside and was approached by a homeless man begging for food. We fed him. Other than that, the food was really great. The Mongolian beef was deliciously tender, the Mushu Wrap was like a fajita and delicious. We also had the roti and curry appetizer, and also the Shrimp fried rice, also both delish!
author: P M.

description:
A great neighborhood spot the only appreciable downside is its popularity- Expect to join those waiting on the corner for ten to twenty minutes. Everything I have had has been good with the with pork rib is awesome! The noodle dishes are The beer selection is more than adequate. The price point is very reasonable you and a date can enjoy a starter and mains with beers for around $50. Maybe there will even be leftovers!

I look forward to returning!
author: Evin W.

description:
So glad a good restaurant moved into this spot! Had the shrimp dumplings (Shu Mai), tempora portabella mushrooms, and the tonkotsu ramen. 

Service was a bit slow, and you could tell they had a very very new dude helping the floor, but the main waitress Naoko was friendly and helpful, and always had a smile on her face.  

LOVED THE RAMEN, and the portabella tempora was delicious. Not a big fan of the shrimp dumplings myself, but my husband dug them, so two outta three ain't bad at all! Thank you spice jar for filling our bellies with delicious, perfectly spiced and seasoned food! Welcome to the neighborhood!
author: Cake S.

description:
This, sir, is no laksa. It tastes like little more than curry powder and coconut milk, some overcooked noodles, sad tofu (not tofu puffs, mind you, just the same dried out fried tofu cubes that come in the green curry tofu), sadder beansprouts, cilantro, and shrimp. No sweetness, no sourness, no shrimp paste. Where where other laksa accessories, like lime wedges, hardboiled eggs, more herb variety, fried shallots, fish balls, chili paste, or long beans? Even one of those would have helped this beige bowl. If you only care about quantity, you'll be satisfied since it was a quart of it.

This was not the only disappointing dish we ordered, but it was the burden in my bowl.
author: Lauren G.

description: Calamari salad, beer and spices chicken miso soup with an extra side of noodles. Can't go wrong with this new place. Owners are also super awesome from Pasadena.
author: Rob A.

description: This place is so delicious! It's only been open for a few months and is located in the Mission just a few blocks from where I live. Soups, noodles, rice dishes and more-- this place is fantastic! The food is spiced perfectly, full of flavor and prepared made to order. I am a vegetarian and requested the Laksa coconut curry soup without the shrimp or chicken. I got to say, it's probably the tastiest Asian soup (ramen-esque) I've ever had the pleasure of eating.
author: Melissa D.

description:
This place is the best! It's an adorable hidden gem in a quiet spot in the mission. Super friendly staff, great ambiance in the tiny space. Get there early to get a table since there aren't many. 

I would eat the crispy calamari salad every day if I could. It's huge and delicious. So so good. You won't regret it. The curry is also fantastic.
author: Amy Y.

description:
They do many things,  and none of them well.   I love laksa.  If you've eaten here and thought this was laksa, please stop.   Please.   It tasted like curry powder in some store bought paste.  And the wrong noodle people.  Gah.  The green curry was average.  The dumplings non memorable.   Even if the wait wasn't 1 hour I wouldn't be back.   The staff was nice even though overwhelmed running their shop.  

If you want a green curry,  go to Basil Thai.  If you want a hybrid Asian place,  Noodle Theory is pretty much what this place is trying to mimic (and not doing it well).  You can probably make the food they're serving here at home with minimal effort.  Trust me.
author: A A.

description:
It is awesome!  Please disregard all other reviews.  Since they have opened I have been 10+ times, some times they have an off night but over all it is amazing.  

It is our go to place to bring friends who are in town.
author: Joe M.

description:
While visiting from LA my wife and I try to seek out restaurants and new experiences while in the Bay area. The Spice Jar is definately worth a visit. It feels like a good date place. Not a date where you're trying to spend alot of money but one where it's two down to earth people wanting good food and conversation. Parking is sparse and the restaurant is small. In my opinion it being small gives it charm.  It's more down home then hipster with a diy light fixture giving off soft light to compliment the decor that's chill yet urban. 

The food was delicious. My wife ordered ramen. She loved the flavor but questioned the texture. Not in a bad way, but just comparing it to other places. She ate it  all. I had mongolian beef. It comes with bread to make a little sandwich but I think I would have enjoyed it more with just the tradition white rice. My cousin ordered the Pho. We all cleaned our plates.

The service was great. They were nice and attentive. The food wasnt too expensive about $20 a person depending on the entree and drink obviously. All in all it was a good experience for Asian comfort food.
author: Anthony S.

description:
After seeing the menu I was very excited to try this place. Unfortunately the food largely lacked in flavor and nothing wow-ed us. The noodle dish was very greasy. 
I love this style of Asian food but frankly it fell flat.
author: Brian M.

description:
The food was great, and came in large portions with reasonable prices.  I would particularly recommend the laska, the roti, and the calamari salad.

However, I don't think I'd go back as it was SO LOUD.  THE LOUDEST.  Being at the communal table in the seat closest to the kitchen surely didn't help, but it's a very small restaurant so it was probably almost as loud everywhere.  We actually pulled out a decibel meter app on the phone and found that the noise hovered between 75-80dB.  It was overwhelming and I wasn't able to hear the person sitting across from me.
author: Alex H.

description: spice jar has become a go-to favorite at least once a week!! the food is off the hook! i'd say it's a mix of japanese and thai - staff/owners are more than friendly, attentive and kind.  if you're a vegetarian, there are TONS of options and all are delicious.  garlic edamame, veggie gyoza, tofu steak w veggies and the green curry w tofu is perfect and more than enough for two!! though you better get there early to put your name down on the list.  they do not take reservations and if you get there after 6:30 pm you'll be waiting at least 30-45 minutes for a table.  i'd eat at spice jar every night if i could!! thank you spice jar.  i am grateful you're in the neighborhood :)
author: Nicki B.

description: What a charming little place. The food and ambience is absolutely fantastic. I had the seafood fondue, and it was delicious. The jalepeno plum wine is so good too!
author: Mark S.

description: Well,  my experience here was a little funny. Spice Jar is located in a space that is NOT plus size friendly. So if you are a curvy person wait for a table by the door and sit with your back to window. IJS. Some of he dishes are almost served like Tapas, especially the 6 hour braised short rib, very short. the fries are crunchy, Meh. My favorite things were the Shumai and The Ramen ( which I pilfered from my friend's bowl LOL).
author: Lydia V.

description:
Came in at 9:10pm on a Wednesday night and crowd was poppin! Your typical hipster crowd in the Mission at this Asian themed joint run by what appears to be a a lovely Japanese couple.

I love the fact that this place is around the corner from me, and the flavors are tasty...but they aren't out of this world. I had the tonkatsu-shoyu ramen and he had the fried rice. Both were solid meals. However, as an Asian duo, we've both had better at several other places. 

This is a good place to take someone who is a picky eater though and likes clean places, as the flavors cater to a palate that isn't too used to ethnic flavors and the restaurant is spotless.
author: Michelle N.

description:
I have recently discovered my new local in SF. whenever I'm around the neighborhood i feel inclined to head over here. They don't have the largest menu around, but it is ample enough to feed 6 picky eaters including vegan, gluten free and carnivores. 

My go to's are the garlic spinach fried rice and their garlic noodles that are perfect in every way.

Check it out but get there early or have a small wait. They have limited seating, but I haven't had to wait too long to get served and when it's nice outside, their outdoor seating is open.
author: Sally S.

description:
I came here with a group of 4 on a Tuesday night. They do not take reservations, but we got there around 7:30pm and there weren't any names on the list yet (though the inside was already full). It was incredibly nice out so we asked to be sat outside. They have a few tables they placed on the sidewalk outside and it was perfect. They were able to sit all four of us immediately out there. 

They only server wine, beer and sake here. They have a small selection but it's all decent. They were incredibly prompt and friendly with getting our drink and appetizer orders in.

None of us knew what to expect, but I can tell you the appetizers blew our socks off! We had the Albacore Carpaccio with Jalapeno sauce. That was so incredibly good- probably the best dish of the night. Highly recommend making a point to get that. We also got the Braised Spare Rib, which also was amazing. Lastly we had the garlic edamame. Not the best I've had, but still somewhat tasty. 

For the main courses we had the Spicy Sesame Miso Ramen. It really wasn't that spicy even with spicy in the name. It was decent. You could probably afford to increase the spiciness across all dishes. We had the Spice Jar Fried rice. It was good, but again not that spicy at medium. 

Overall the experience was just lovely, the food was good and definitely a place I'd come back. They were all very nice!
author: Annette D.

description:
By far my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. The owners are so incredibly amazing and talented and always welcoming. The food is fantastic and I always leave soooo happy! I love the lettuce cups, albacore carpaccio, the tofu, seafood curry, seaweed salad, and all of the beautiful sake's they have in individual painted cups! This place is a complete gem and I will wait in line however long to eat and support this wonderful local and independent business.
Your the best spice jar!
Had my birthday party there this here at the long communal table, they were so accomodating!
author: Paris I.

description: Love the spice jar. It's a little pricey but I almost always take some home for lunch the next day because it's a lot of food so I can spread it out  over two meals. I got the Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen and the spring rolls and both were awesome.
author: Kathleen C.

description:
Went by myself on a Fri. Definitely more of a date spot, as I came to realize. Very small and intimate setting.

Had the vegetable rolls and laksa. Both tasted amazing and came out piping hot. They wider variety of beers then I expected, which is always a plus from me.

The waiters/waitresses were incredibly nice and constantly checked in on me.
author: Kyle K.

description: Ate here at night. The food was decent but not really good. I think if you want something simple this place is good but it's a bit on the pricy side for that. We got the bao, tonkatsu ramen, and the steak wrap. Don't get stake wrap, it's literally just a steak fajitas. The ramen was decent, pretty thick, but really nothing special. I tried the sesame ramen they offered and that was much more unique and tasty. The bao is basically a spare rib with hoisen sauce in a bun (includes bone). It was tasty, but nothing really unique. If you come here, get sesame ramen and other things.
author: Victor D.

description:
3.5 stars

Interesting and cute Asian fusion cafe.  I think they are in their honeymoon phase right now and are overwhelmed with popularity.  So, be prepared to wait.  There were only two parties ahead of us late on a weeknight and it took us about an hour to finally get seated.  However, the owners were SUPER friendly and conscientious.  They noticed that we had been waiting quite a while for especially chatty SF elitists who had finished dinner, already paid, yet still would not relinquish their seats even though there was a line of people waiting to get seated!  So, the owners sat us outside for a bit, served us water, and complimentary garlic edamame.  Which was delicious, by the way.  They were really sweet...which is also why I hesitate to say that although some of the food was fantastic, some of it was not as impressive as I would have hoped.  Which hurts me to say because they seem like super nice people--serious dilemma, but I have to speak the truth!

Pork Bao - This was the bomb dot com.  HUUUUGE chunka pork that was doused in some delicious barbecue served on a steamed bun.  Very flavorful and super tender.  Slightly difficult to hold and eat though without making a mess.  But, they serve it with wet napkins to clean up before/after.  Thoughtful!  P.S. the pork is still attached to the bone, so before you chomp down, make sure that you take the bone out first!

Chicken Karaage - Nicely fried without being too greasy.  It was crispy and piping hot when it arrived.  Both of the guys I was dining with loved this dish but I wasn't as "in love" with it.  But maybe that's because fried food just isn't my thing.  It was good, don't get me wrong but I would take the steamed pork bao over it any day.

Har Gaw - Wanted to love this...really wanted to.  I love those Cantonese shrimp steamed dumplings with the clear chewy skin but these were oversteamed.  The skin was a bit too thick and started breaking apart.  The shrimp pieces were generous but did not taste too fresh which left a strange aftertaste in my mouth.

Tonkatsu Ramen - Ramen broth was thick and delicious without being overpowering and the noodles were also spot on.  The meat was good too, very similar to the pork in the pork bao.  But, the egg was not hard-boiled and the saffron was just too overwhelming.  I know that they were trying to make it a more fusion dish but the saffron was too much.  It actually detracted from the rest of the dish--even if it did look more decorative.

I think the food has potential and I'd like to try some of the other dishes but only 2 out of 5 really blew me away.  But, although the food was so-so, the service and atmosphere were fantastic.

The space itself is small but really cute.  I love the branch/lightbulb chandelier.  The lightbulbs are all unique and it's really cute.  I also love the quote on the wall: "People who love to eat are always the best people" because duh.
author: Jess Y.

description: Best pho ga in SF!! Such a cute little restaurant with awesome service! Love homey friendly places. Can't get better comfort food on a cold winter day!
author: Shanna N.

description: I have now been to The Spice Jar 2 times and I am very impressed with the quaintness of this neighborhood joint and the excellent food.. The dishes are large and very filling. My favorite is the calamari salad which I split with my boyfriend and a bowl of their yummy soups always hit the spot..It's always crowded but well worth the wait.. Very reasonable for what you get..
author: Stacy I.

description:
Showed up at 1130 for lunch w 2 friends from a local business... Not tech! 
A variety of patrons served with class by  very friendly server.
I had the ramen ...and green tea ... tasty and filling.
If you're not some finicky foodie neurotic you might really like this place!
author: Robert B.

description: Not something I realized from other reviews: a bit of a hole in the wall, separated from the buzz of Valencia street by a nice, leisurely walk. This place is adorable, and delicious. On a rainy San Francisco day, I recommend getting one of the soups -- the curry coconut broth was exceptional.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
I came here because of all the great reviews on Yelp and I wanted to give it s try. I saw they had Korean steak Bowl wanted to try it. The guy tells  me they only have it for lunch. (Okay then take it off the special sign, all you have to do is erase it.. Don't advertise that you have it.) fine I asked the server is the other beef dish fatty? I explained to him a lot of places I go to have fatty beef. He said so very good quality. So j order it and he explained the fish came with some rice. And I ordered the chicken miso ramen. Brought everything home. And I was so disappointed. The ramen was so fucking hot!! I totally scorched my tongue!  I'm talking THIRD DEGREE BURN people. Where my tongue started peeling!!! Like hello who the hell serves soup that hot!! No warning then can at least write caution hot or at least tell me!! And secondly that beef Dish was so fatty and chewy. I'm never coming here again. And this morning the day after I totally got the shits. I'm taking MASSIVE DIARRHEA!!  

Don't come here. It's not all that. Everyone who is saying it's good has never tried good Chinese food. And  we live in San Francisco we are surround by better places that are a lot cheaper with rice that isn't all hard and crusty! 


Never again bull crap spice jar bill shit
author: Chenea P.

description:
I really like this place. It's local for me and I just keep coming back. The people who operate this place are soooooooooo nice. Seriously. And it's just such a cute corner spot. I kinda don't want to write a good review for them because I want to keep this place accessible but at the same time I wish them all the success in the world :D

Oh yeah, food's great (especially the ramen). And the drinks are fantastic. 

Love the whole package
author: Russ L.

description: A super adorable and cozy spot with beautiful bright light. Delicious food and great service. The laksa is dense and flavorful. The meat on the pork rib in the tonkotsu ramen falls right off of the bone. So good! Keep in mind that this is Asian fusion. If you are looking for authentic laksa then it might throw you off. But if you are looking for tasty comforting Asian flavors... this is it! Side note - they serve the ginger beer with real ginger and it was real cool!
author: Nana L.

description:
Cute little spot owned by a really sweet Japanese couple! 
Food was delicious - best chicken karage ever. The spare rib bao was spot on. The laksa was a bit of a miss - not authentic, more Japanese curry like but still delicious. 
Overall a great place for a casual dinner - will be back to try the rest of the menu....
author: Bhavnak K.

description: Went to this spot the other night and loved it! It's not the most authentic Asian food, but it's delicious and it's definitely "comfort food." It's easy, delicious food but definitely not the spot you want to go to if you're looking for super authentic Chinese dumplings or mushu wraps. We will be back for sure.
author: Erica V.

description: Great place! Good choices--- we had the laksa which was very tasty and the spice jar fried rice.  Definitely recommend the laksa   The fried rice was good but not incredible.  Staff was really friendly and nice despite a busy evening    I really liked the reataurant ambience: Small and cute with an open kitchen.  We will definitely come back to try some other items on the menu!
author: N S.

description: The fish was good, but the garlic green beans are more filling. The rice is undercooked. Wasabi Ale tastes OK, but not worth chugging down, actually.
author: Kokoe J.

description:
Came here on the the first day they opened and my friend and I were lucky enough to snag the last table before the rush came in. 

We ordered:

Braised Spare Ribs Bao -- The thing was HUGE! I was expecting a smaller bao, kind of like peiking duck style. But this thing was more like a cross between a bao and a taco if you will. The meat was really tender and came off the bone, just like the waitress said. Even though there was a bone in it, the amount of meat they gave us was still pretty generous. The bao was very thick and doughy. The combination of the two was a disaster in my mouth. Although the meat had a decent flavor to it, the bread completely overpowered the meat, and it was difficult to swallow because it was so dry. The pickled veggies helped, but not too much. After the first bite, I ended up eating the bao and the meat separately. Even though it wasn't intended to be served that way, it tasted much better in my opinion.

Har Gow -- One order comes with four har gows, but they separate the har gows into two steamers so they don't stick together. There is also a piece of lettuce between the har gows and the steamer, maybe to keep it from sticking to the steamer or for sanitary reasons perhaps? I'm not quite sure. The skin of the har gow is really thick, unlike traditional har gows. It comes very close to tasting like bao to me. The skin is very sticky, so it sticks really well to the steamer and the lettuce, and I completely destroyed one of the har gows before I even got it onto my plate. :( The prawns were huge! But, the har gows soaked in the flavor of the lettuce in the steamer, which took away even more of the authenticity of the har gows. :(

Shu Mai -- The most authentic dish that we ordered, in my opinion.  They were slightly smaller than the har gows, but not by much. The texture of the skin was thin, and the filling had a good pork to mushroom ratio. The mushroom is subtly more noticeable than the pork, just how I like it.

Garlic Aonori Fries -- They were surprisingly good! Most likely just frozen Sysco fries with garlic aonori powder. But I'm not complaining! I could sit in front of the TV and eat these all day!

Zen Noodle Soup -- The waitress said this dish is one of the few dishes that the owner bought over from the previous restaurant due to is popularity. She had a lot of good things to say about it, so it felt wrong not to order it. However, I am a wimp and cannot handle spicy foods, we asked them to tweak it a little bit and make it as mild as possible. This was also the last dish to come out, so we were already pretty full by the time it go to us. The soup had good flavor, but it was a little sour for my liking. They use rounded rice noodles for the dish. There was surprisingly a lot of seafood also. The were only a few pieces of calamari, which were slightly chewy, but still tender enough for me to swallow. The shrimp was a bit overcooked, but that's usually the case when you order shrimp with a soup. They were very generous with the mussels, and it was probably the best part of the dish. The mussels were on the smaller side, but I guess the amount they gave us made up for it.

Wasabi Ale -- Not my cup of ale. Very interesting taste. I thought the taste was similar to some sort of powder mix. I really wanted to like it because of how unique it was, but my taste buds said no. :( My friend enjoyed it, so I just let him drink all of it.

The place is pretty small. They could seat maybe 25-30 people or so. When we walked in, they were trying to fix the balance on one of the tables. The aisles were pretty narrow too, and it was difficult to not bump into other parties when we walked out. Decent food, but clearly, they have a few kinks to work out.
author: Vivian L.

description:
Oh my gosh. Please don't come here. (I mean, of course, you can.) But seriously, every single dish we tried was so good in this new find that for the first time in my life I'd rather hide it than share.

Har gow = delicious, mochi-like dumpling wrappers and YUM on the inside
Portabello tempura = savory mushroom slices flashed into fries. Ask for some of the mu shu steak sauce (the green one) to combine with the sambal for a tastebud-loving dip
Sesame Miso Ramen, vegetarian = Are you veg but sad that there are so many delicious meat and seafood dishes? They'll happily customize the Sesame Miso ramen. Gobs of fresh veggies and an out-of-this-world broth made this my favorite ramen in the city. Ramen Underground pork quality, local Mission location and veggie taste/bodyfeel. Impossible...
Mu Shu Hangar Steak = I tried a mushroom from this dish, dipped in sauce, and instantly teleported to heaven.

Jasmine tea was delicious, service was super humble and kind with great humor, location quiet and safe, and I will be back here as often as possible.

Please be kind while in the neighborhood and note, they're currently closed on Mondays... be gentle to avoid breaking your own heart.

Yay spice jar!!
author: Megan G.

description: Place is good . Simple , small and cozy . Usually very busy . They have good beer selection. The one negative thing about my visit , was the eggs they use ... fried rice is a simple dish and boxed eggs just don't cut it . Otherwise good . I would go back there again .
author: Angelica R.

description: I'm not an adventurous eater so I was a little worried when I saw the menu. Gotta say, I ate everything that came to the table and my favorite was the albacore carpaccio! Next favorite and it was a close tie, was the shrimp dumpling. So tasty! Also loved the Mongolian beef and the crispy calamari salad. The ramen could have used more flavor and the seafood fondue had a strange taste I couldn't quite place. Otherwise, all was really really good. Go and check them out!
author: Tera K.

description: Amazing food and great service! Really loved all the options and had such a hard time deciding what to get. Also loved that they had unfiltered cold sake, our waitress even said it was made in her home town!
author: Annika L.

description: It is nice to have another Asian restaurant around SFGH/ Mission. It has a cool vibe inside and the staff is very friendly. I had the pork tonkotsu ramen and the broth was just right, and pork was very tender. It was not too crowded around lunch time when I went. There is also nice outdoor seating. Can't wait for my next meal here to try something else.
author: Jaime F.

description: The owners, chef, and waiter are all welcoming. The options offer a good range of pan Asian cuisine.  Each is well prepared, and served in a gracious and friendly environment.  The music is good and the decor is great. A good total experience.
author: Nathaniel H.

description:
I came here with a group of 6 around 6:15 and waited about 40 minutes- 1 hr. The place is smaller than I expected, but nice and cozy. The previous group was there for 2 hours and refused to leave.... which is why we had to wait so long but the owner was very kind to us and apologized.

Things ordered:
aonori fries - yummy! good snack for drinking
veggie spring rolls - kinda greasy but good portion, and they cut it in half 
green curry - surprisingly tasty for a fusion restaurant
tofu steak - very flavorful and meaty!
jalapeno plum wine - refreshing but could use a few more slices of jalapeno

overall good experience, and I like how there are so many veggie friendly options.
author: Tina K.

description:
Done! tried this place last night and it was as good as it gets. Asian comfort food, the albacore carpaccio is a must! 

And, the flank steak was cooked perfectly, which comes with tortillas and a nice aji style sauce with a creamy hint. Divine. 

The aged sake was super good - with nice stone fruit notes and a delicate butterscotch-ish finish. 

Enjoy it!
author: Gilmar A.

description:
Love the Tonkutsu Ramen!  Must order!!!!

The owner was super nice. Table for 3, 2 adults and 1 kid under 2. The little one made a mess, splashed water all over the floor and dropped a quarter of her meal. The owner did not show a sight of unhappiness. God Bless her!  She deserved a good tip and 5 stars review.
author: anita s.

description:
3.5 stars really, adding half start for the awesome service.

The asian fusion here is unique in a way that it brings cuisines from all parts of asia from japan to india and everything in between. There are definitely some unique items on the menu that would be hard to find elsewhere but somehow i left feeling slightly underwhelmed

We had the shrimp dumplings and cast iron seafood fondue which were probably the highlights. For mains, we had the laksa and the salmon both of which were above average but nothing spectacular. 

I'd definitely frequent this place if i lived in the area or happened to be in the neighborhood but I dont think i'll  make a plan to come back.

There is a LOT really good asian food in SF which makes competition really tough and while this place is a solid B+ it just falls short of an A for me
author: Aditya J.

description:
Let's get the not so amazing things out of the way:

1) The rice was dry
2) the wait for seating and for my order to arrive was long (a problem that faces many new restaurants )
3) No knives available at the table to cut your food. 
4) Tasteless side salad (no dressing) left much to be desired. 

In the end the menu felt a bit over-priced and I was tempted to give Spice Jar 3 stars...

But the service was great! The staff at Spice Jar really care about you and are trying very hard to give you a pleasant, delicious experience. They are friendly and cheerful and aware of the fact that many of their patrons are waiting in long lines to eat (a fact that is made evident by their generous offerings of free edamame)  pulling my rating into the 4-star region. 

So, I do not recommend going any time in the next few weeks (there are still some logistic items for them to figure out) but I feel that in a month or two things will really have settled down and the menu and speed will have been adjusted enough to really be a gem of the Mission district. I am happy they are here and look forward to my visit again in a month.
author: Drago F.

description: Workers are friendly and they make sure water is always on your table. The food was okay. The shu mai comes in 4 and it is extremely hot so let it cool. I got the tonkatsu ramen and it was okay. I don't know if I was really full from the shu mai but I couldn't finish it. My boyfriend got the Laksa(?). It's a coconut based dish with your choice of ramen noodles or rice I believe. It's good but has a kick to it. It's like curry!
author: Jessica L.

description:
The perfect blend of oil and water, 
my lips are sticky with satisfaction,
temperature rising, impression guaranteed. 

Start here...
Sparerib Ramen 
Albacore Carpaccio
Cast Iron Seafood Fondu
author: Jay Z.

description: What an incredible meal! I've had this place bookmarked for some time now, and took my gf out on a night we were having a particularly hard time deciding what to eat. The wait was only about 10 minutes long on a Thursday night. The menu featured some interesting items both familiar and new, so we chose to go with the shu mai pork dumplings and short rib bao as appetizers, followed by the Mongolian beef and laksa soup. The shu mai were good but nothing too special. The short rib bao is something I would definitely come back for, though. The beef is so tender, and is perfect wrapped in the bun with all that sauce! The Mongolian beef had good flavors, and the portion is adequate but not worth $14. The Laksa soup was definitely worth every penny. Super delicious!
author: Gabriela M.

description:
I love discovering new little gems in San Fran. I want to keep this place a secret so it doesn't get over run by fellow San Franciscans, but I also want to spread the word so people can share in the delight.  Asian fusion restaurants are typically hard to pull off normally because chefs can throw a menu together that has breadth, but no depth.  Such was not the case with Spice Jar. The menu was thoughtfully curated and every morsel we ate was so tasty. 

We ordered the calarmari salad, tonkatsu ramen and shu-mai - again, all delicately made and delish!  We kept praising the owner every time he walked by because we loved it so much.
author: S C.

description: Zen noodle soup is very tasty, ordered a side of jasmine rice and I couldn't finish it... They put lots of mussels, shrimp, and oysters in it... But even on top of all that the coconut broth was mesmerizing ... Date night???  simple dish lots of flavor
author: Danny S.

description:
I love the vibes of this place. It feels really nice in there
I tried the laksa $11 and it's just delicious. The staff are great too.
There's sometimes some queue, but it goes fast.
Totally recommend it
author: Sophie G.

description: New Asian Cuisine Restaurant. Many small bites and fancy foods. Also you can taste many kinds Sake and Shochu here! The are many parking spot around the restaurant.
author: Tetsuro M.

description: Great service.  Good food.  Cute place! Totally satisfied! Must try their homemade tofu.  Homemade fresh mint ginger lemonade.  For sure to come back with friends!
author: Emiliy L.

description: Vibrant, fresh and wonderful flavors is how I'd describe their food.  We had the poke bowl and bbq beef bowl and it was a huge hit!!  Ive been wondering what all those long lines meant and why there was always a wait--now I know.  A must-try if you are in the Mission.  One of the best asian restaurants in town!
author: Jez S.

description:
Asian fusion restaurant that is a great new addition to this end of the Mission.  I have now been here a couple times.  The food is very good and very fresh.  Recommendations.....get the Hanger Steak BBQ Mushu Wraps.  It is kind of like super tasty asian fajitas.  Also the Crispy Spring rolls which are nice and crunchy.  Also the Spice Jar Fried Rice,  which is a healthy portion to share amounts your table.

Selection of beer and wine.  I like that they do their wine by different carafe sizes so you can have more than a glass without committing to a bottle. Only downside is the place is a bit small and can get crowded especially on a weekend night.
author: Jax B.

description:
It makes my heart sad to write this review but I feel I must. This is such a quaint and perfect little corner spot. I feel as though they deserve all of the accolades but fear it will mean long lines for me and my rumbling stomach once the secret is out. The food is consistently prepared with meticulous attention to detail and always comes out hot. The aroma hits you as soon as you walk in and you know you are somewhere special. 
Everything on the menu is good. Everything. There I said it. Don't lose out by trying only one dish. Do yourself a favor a get a sampling of something new each time you go and you won't be disappointed. Their food is comforting, healthy and fresh and do not pass on the ginger lemonade. 
Every time I leave this place with a full belly I feel as though mom and dad just took care of me and gave me a rare treat and a kiss on the forehead to go. Please just don't go bragging about this place to just anybody. Keep it special. Tell the ones who really get it. The rest can eat at some fancy uppity place downtown. This one is a total gem.
author: Ronald B.

description: It was pretty good. It's really tiny. GARLIC EDEMAME.
author: Areeb M.

description: Recommend the veggie ramen and mushroom lettuce bowls. Also impressive sake list and enjoyable sake from a cute jar. Amazing service and atmosphere. Wait list was efficiently organized and well worth it.
author: Malia B.

description: Great addition to the Mission. If you're down with MCF and Yamo but want something with more ambiance, then this is the spot. Awesome food, prices and staff!
author: Ryan O.

description:
Discovered this place on Yelp on a whim - my friend and I were spending the day in San Francisco and found ourselves in the Mission District around dinner time. It had good reviews so we decided to check it out.

These reviews are totally deserved! The food here is so flavorful and a mix of different Asian cuisines. I had garlic edamame and the spinach fried rice - both delicious and VERY rich in flavor. I also had the ginger ice cream for dessert which was definitely the highlight of the meal - tasted like fresh ginger with just the right amount of sweetness.
The customer service was also great. The staff was prompt and very helpful. Highly recommend this place if you're looking for a tasty and fairly affordable dinner!
author: Sanika B.

description: Cute little place with friendly attentive service. I only tried the tonkatsu ramen which was good, not the best I've had. The spare rib in the soup was very good. Interested to try some of the other items.
author: Eric C.

description: My favorite place to visit when I am in SF. I LOVE this place. Everything I've had there is flavorful, lots of impact, and I am craving the Laksa as I write this. Calamari salad is A MUST TRY!
author: Yuki A.

description:
The food here was amazing!

I came her with a group of six. There is limited seating so ended up having to wait 45 minutes, but was totally worth it!

We got a variety of dishes, I tried: portobello mushroom tempura (YUM!), laska and green curry. Great vibe, would highly recommend it.
author: Saira Z.

description:
Outstanding. 

Had the green curry and a variety of apps and all were cooked to perfection and tasted amazing. Staff is very attentive and genuinely appreciative of their customers. We got there relatively early but by the time we left there were several folks waiting outside. It's a small place so be prepared to wait. It's well worth it.
author: Mark S.

description: I love the shu mai, the noodle soups because of the brilliant broths and the calamari salad. Also, get the fresh made lemonade. It has mint and ginger in it and it's delicious. The only downside of the place is that it's closed on monday.
author: Michael W.

description: I'm from San Jose and went out on a limb to take a drive out on a rainy day. I ended up ordering garlic noodles and shu mai and found myself very satisfied with the meal. Totally worth the drive!
author: Sam A.

description: We had a fantastic meal here on a Saturday night. We arrived around 9PM and still waited about 20 minutes to get a table. Parking nearby was really tough to find. The ambiance on the inside is really small, warm, and cozy! The service was also very friendly. The food was fantastic and everyone at the table really enjoyed their meal. I had the red curry which was so decadent and I'd recommend if you're in the mood for Thai Curry. We will definitely be back! Only wish they took reservations, I hate waiting!
author: Kendra N.

description: Spicy miso ramen is addictive. We live around the corner and Spice Jar is our go-to most work nights. The couple who own it are wonderful and thoughtful. So happy to help support this restaurant for locals ;)
author: Bradford S.

description:
Cute, friendly with da bomb food! 

Spice Jar fried rice - must have! You know something is delicious when you feel a slight sadness that with each delicious bite...less of it is left to eat...sigh. I thought this was the star of the night 

Spring rolls - Yummy! 

Lettuce cups - it was so good that we ended up ordering another round of them. 

Calamari Salad - Yummy!

Portions are HUGE! We rarely have leftovers bc my hubs can eat volume, but we met our match here. 

Service was so friendly and inviting. Highly recommend! Great date spot!
author: Candace D.

description: Mongolian Lamb was killer. My favorite part was the ginger mint lemonade! The spicy miso ramen looked really good too.
author: Drew L.

description:
Awesome Asian comfort food! Soooo delicious and the quality is top notch! 

Ramen is great! 
Fried Calamari Salad is a MUST!
Ginger mint lemonade is very refreshing!

The owner was a chef at a large Japanese restaurant and it shows. There is deep and thoughtful intentionality in all his dishes and you can taste his dedication to his craft.
author: Kevin K.

description: We went here in a group of six last week and were blown away. Excellent food, variety, portions, prices and service. There was a bit of a wait but well worth it. Must try the mongolian chicken, calamari salad and the pho ga!
author: Kabir S.

description: WOW! This is really good Asian Fusion food that is prepared with care and tastes great! Prices are very fair and while it's a bit cramped, you'll find it is worth the wait. You are here for the food not the ambiance. Service is good. Nice selection of wine and beer to go with the delicious food. We were here for lunch. Try the Shumai for a starter. We had Tonkatsu Ramen, Laksa and spare rib bua- all were tasty! We were happy and full when we left.
author: Mike K.

description: My husband and I had dinner at the Spice Jar based on other positive Yelp reviews and we were not disappointed. The food was good, flavorful, and fresh. I would suggest you don't come with a large party (anything more than 3) unless you have the time to wait and the right jackets to wait outside. On to the food the Braised Sparerib Bao was really good but small. The cucumbers really made a difference in the flavor of the Braised Sparerib.  The Calamari Salad which was a healthy sized portion had plenty of calamari and flavor to serve as a main dish. The Laksa Soup Noodle was also really good, generously portioned and packed with tons of flavor. In addition to nice ambience, good food and friendly service the food was very well priced our bill was $ 44 in my opinion you can't beat that. We'd definitely come back.
author: Lumei M.

description: I Love This  Place! Awesome food, prepared simply, with the sweetest owners ever. The couple from Kobe who creates this place did a great job. Yay!
author: Gina O.

description: good restaurant，but I think the salad is just so so. The noodles seems good,but I did not try
author: Ling C.

description: This place is ridiculously good!!! From the experience to the food to the ambience. The calamari salad is BOMB! Best food ever. I can't say enough good stuff. The owner was super cool and interacted with us. He was so sweet and humble. His wife works there too. So cute! I will drive from Sacramento just to eat at this place any day!!! Busy as well which shows a lot. Only been opened for 6 months! Wow. Also the ginger lemonade is perfect !
author: Jessica D.

description: Perfection in the kitchen and relaxed but helpful service. Come here before this place becomes overwhelmed!
author: Ivan B.

description: I heard about this quaint restaurant a few months ago, and while I was in town around mission, I decided to bring my parents here. It was amazing like I expected. I had the Mongolian Lamb with rice and bread and it was spectacular. My parents who are usually pretty cynical about Asian fusion restaurants, but they loved it. The fried rice and the ramen (which usually is extremely hard to please). The staff is amazing and I highly recommend!
author: Taylor H.

description: Chez Maman or the Spice Jar. Hmm... It's a toss up and you can't go wrong with either for dinner. One of my TOP 10 restaurants in SF 'nough said. When you come here, order as much as you can afford cuz it'll be worth it.
author: Joshua F.

description: I wanted to try this place for my birthday and I was happy that I did. The spice jar did not disappoint. Started off with the short rib bao and it was tasty, the meat was falling off the bone. Next we had the shu mai, they were succulent and big. The fried chicken was next and it was perfectly fried and very flavorful. Last we had the fried calamari salad and what a great way to end our meal! I enjoyed everything that evening and the service was great. The owner was attentive and very nice! Hope to be back real soon
author: Ingrid J.

description: AMAZING food. would get 5 stars except their kitchen/staff gets backed up sometimes and one time it took us an excessively long time to eat (close to 3 hours)
author: natalie c.

description: I generally try to eat somewhere new every week, but I had this place last weekend and had to come back again. Ordered 4 entrees and they were all amazing, savory, great texture, and well presented. The place is a great mix of Asian-Californian cusisine and there are options for everyone. Although the place isn't huge, it's well lit with cool decorations inside. I'll be back again.
author: Slaiman A.

description: Delightfully chill space next to bustling 24th street corridor and the the Zuck space at SF General. Pan-asian food disguises expert craft behind simple-appearing specialities like poke, ramen, fried rice. Excellent beer list and outdoor tables.
author: Allonsy A.

description: We had the green curry with chicken and the mongolian chicken. Both were just amazing. By far the best and most savoury green curry i've eaten so far.
author: Mathieu H.

description: We live 2 blocks away from this place, and are still not sick of it. Delicious food, great service, and you feel so good after you eat it. Better eaten in the restaurant as opposed to take out.
author: Britt B.

description: Small place, tasty food. The salmon had a delicious crust. Everything was rich and flavorful. The staff was friendly, professional, and competent. A boisterous, convivial atmosphere, loud enough to be lost in the crowd, but easy to chat with everyone at your table. A great spot.
author: Steve S.

description: I like it a lot. You can tell from the ingredients and tastes that the food is prepared with hearts. The seafood noodle soup has little spicy taste which I like most.
author: Quan Y.

description: We have been here a few times with our little kids, and it's a neighborhood gem!  The calamari salad was light and delicious, Ramen is delicious, and their fried rice is great!  Wonderful service and a great value.  This is becoming one of our favorite neighborhood grub spots.
author: Ashley + Kelvin Q.

description: Atmosphere is nice inside, small and cozy. Surprisingly always a wait for a small local cuisine. Food is amazing. The chicken lettuce wraps had a smokey chat taste that was unreal. Braised rib is savory, and the albacore carpaccio is incredible, a must have. Mongolian beef and garlic noodles were full of flavor and had a little kick to them. Staff was friendly. Definitely recommend.
author: Kalani M.

description: Absolutely the best Asian cuisine in town! And what great hospitality! You truly feel at home in Chef Hamada's kitchen. The chef and his wife personally attend your table, so special. Must tries: hanger steak, albacore carpaccio, & the Bao braised rib appetizer.
author: Nicole F.

description: Mind and heart blown. Can't remember the last time I had such a delicious and reasonably priced meal, in a cute comfortable restaurant. Stop reading reviews and go eat here
author: Afaan N.

description:
A nice little spot. Menu is small, but what they do they do well.

It's also reasonably priced for the area/a trendy spot. 

We had the shu mai pork dumplings (excellent) and beef short rib ramen. I would recommend both, but pass on the cucumber salad. 

Their iced green tea is super refreshing and comes with free refills (it also seems to have some matcha in it).
author: Devyn R.

description: What an amazing find!!  My husband has been wanting to check this place out, and we finally had the time to stop in. It was Valentine's day and there was no wait.  It's labeled Asian comfort food.. and it did not disappoint.  We started off with the fried chicken bites. Yum.  Crispy, perfect little nuggets of happiness!!  With a tasty remoulade dipping sauce.  We then got the chicken sesame ramen.  So tasty.  Not a traditional ramen in that there aren't a lot of veggies or egg in it, but you don't miss it.. so much flavor!!!!  And the spice jar fried rice.. it has a little bit of everything in it. This was a pretty big portion.. enough to share.  Everything was cooked to order and served promptly. Highly recommend.  I will be back.  The only drawback is that is it's a tiny place, and you are super close to people you don't know... But if you are friendly and social, the should be no problem.
author: Mindy Z.
